On the China Division, the alignment piece where you have KFC, Taiwan and Thailand moving to YRI during the first quarter, we'll provide you restated numbers as we go and we can give you some ideas. It's not that significant in terms of the revenues and profits, margins. I would suffice to say margins will be a little bit higher when you take those two businesses out. But we'll give you the restatements as the year goes on.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding YRI, I think what we saw in 2009 was that we had very strong sales in first part of the year and then gradually weakening with the global economy. So I won't look at it as a huge change in trend that occurred in the last month, but there's just
componenttext: Regarding YRI, I think what we saw in 2009 was that we had very strong sales in first part of the year and then gradually weakening with the global economy. So I won't look at it as a huge change in trend that occurred in the last month, but there's just been a general softening. Again, hard to predict what's going to happen in 2010 when the global economy's going to strengthen but I don't see any huge changes in trends at this point.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Biggest change in trend over the year actually if you look at it for YRI in particular was check average decline during the year. And Rick mentioned this earlier in his comments that a lot of it was pricing rolling off. That was certainly reflected in the
componenttext: Biggest change in trend over the year actually if you look at it for YRI in particular was check average decline during the year. And Rick mentioned this earlier in his comments that a lot of it was pricing rolling off. That was certainly reflected in the YRI sales earlier in the year, there was still pricing. By the end of the year that was pretty much gone and then also trade down by the consumer. So it was a fair amount of check average impact to that to YRI's growth as the year went on.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Sara Senatore with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Sara Senatore with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that your margins obviously are up versus where they were a couple of years ago despite the fact that we've had some, on average, negative comp over the past two years. And then I know there was some commodity inflation but in fact, it does
componenttext: You mentioned that your margins obviously are up versus where they were a couple of years ago despite the fact that we've had some, on average, negative comp over the past two years. And then I know there was some commodity inflation but in fact, it does look like your food paper as a percentage has come down. So I guess I'm trying to get at is for your company operating margins, can you bucket out what piece of this is maybe just operational improvements versus mix? More Taco Bell's that is of a higher margin versus what kind of benefits you get from refranchising. So to the extent that you refranchise them, the lower margin restaurants, has that been helping too?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The refranchising piece on margins for the year was 40 basis points, so four tenths of a point. The rest of it was the impact of commodities, net of pricing and then productivity initiatives.
componenttext: The refranchising piece on margins for the year was 40 basis points, so four tenths of a point. The rest of it was the impact of commodities, net of pricing and then productivity initiatives.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: That's the challenge. Obviously, the pricing and the commodities pieces occurred in different points in time. So what happened in 2008 is we had rapid commodity inflation in the U.S. I think the number was $119 million for the full year. And it kept going
componenttext: That's the challenge. Obviously, the pricing and the commodities pieces occurred in different points in time. So what happened in 2008 is we had rapid commodity inflation in the U.S. I think the number was $119 million for the full year. And it kept going up as the year progressed. So we were sort of chasing our call pricing in the U.S. in 2008 and then we were getting rollover benefits in 2009. But we're pretty much done with most of our pricing actions by the fourth quarter, the benefit of 2008. So we got very little benefit. We got benefits from pricing up until through the third quarter 2009 and then very little benefit in the fourth quarter. Regarding mix, we're getting some favorable mix on margins. First of all, globally as China becomes a bigger part of the mix, and in the U.S, as Taco Bell is becoming a bigger part of the mix as Tim talked about.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: You've already touched on the YRI part of this question but I was hoping that with your ability to really look into the China market to really explain the deceleration that we saw in the 2009 and obviously ending the year on a low note at down three, the
componenttext: You've already touched on the YRI part of this question but I was hoping that with your ability to really look into the China market to really explain the deceleration that we saw in the 2009 and obviously ending the year on a low note at down three, the thought was we'd be lapping the economic slowdown in the fourth quarter of 2008 and especially, you have a had a meaningful slowdown that you saw to December. So if you could just make some more specific comments in terms of maybe on a macro basis, what you think drove a slowdown in sales throughout the year? And I know in the past, you've talked about things like consumer confidence and savings rate and what have you. What do you think the best economic indicators are for us to look at to try to really say okay, well if this is improving, then Yum!'s business should be improving as well?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's not just one measure. When we look at it and we're not economists, but when we look at measures, we tend to look at a portfolio. So we're looking at consumer confidence. We look at the export markets and we look at sort of the GNP, some guide
componenttext: I think it's not just one measure. When we look at it and we're not economists, but when we look at measures, we tend to look at a portfolio. So we're looking at consumer confidence. We look at the export markets and we look at sort of the GNP, some guidelines. And in terms of 2009, I'll just repeat, even though same-store sales bounced around a little bit, we just sort felt the consumer was pretty level the whole time. It was bad and they never -- you had months when it looks better, worse, et cetera. But I would just sort of categories at least from our perspective, John, is the consumer was pretty much down a bit all year in 2009. I don't think we're going to get a good read, as we sort of said earlier, until after the Chinese New Year. And that's because Chinese New Year overall is always very event-driven and it's a little bit like Christmas in the U.S. You'll have some types of people who'll spend in holidays and they'll not spend in non-holiday period. So when we get into our second quarter, which is sort of starting at March in China, that's when we'll really have bad on bad [ph] economic numbers. Again, the economy in China started weakening really around the December time frame. But if you look at some of the measures around consumer confidence, et cetera, they really bottomed out really in the first quarter of 2009. So it will be interesting for us to see what happens when we sort of lap with the bad economy and we get the noise out of the Chinese New Year. So what we'll be looking at is how do those measures progress especially as we get past February.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the only thing I would add to this is that what do we have in China in 2009? 1.4 million average unit volumes, 20% margins at KFC, 1.2 million average unit volumes, 19% margins at Pizza Hut. That's pretty good base to build from. That says you hav
componenttext: I think the only thing I would add to this is that what do we have in China in 2009? 1.4 million average unit volumes, 20% margins at KFC, 1.2 million average unit volumes, 19% margins at Pizza Hut. That's pretty good base to build from. That says you have a really, really healthy business and that we're well-positioned. I think the other thing I would say is, do we think we are capacity constraint at KFC and Pizza Hut? Absolutely not. We have stores that do twice that volume, those average unit volume. So we can have $2 million average unit volumes at KFC over time. We can have $2 million average unit volumes at Pizza Hut over time as we become even more dominant in casual dining. So to me, what do you have? What do you have with KFC and Pizza Hut in China? I think we have two consumer brands everybody wishes they had, with unbelievable sales and unbelievable unit economics. And I think we have a tremendous return that allows us to continue to grow with lots of confidence. And that's the real name in the game for us, it's to take advantage of the new unit, and the development opportunity and grow KFC into well over 10,000 units and grow Pizza Hut as well. So I think that's how we look at the business. We couldn't be happier with where we're at in China and I think a lot of investors feel the same way.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I know one measure that gets a lot of attention is the GDP and what happens to that growth rate and when does your business [indiscernible]  Around that. Again, I would say there's some analogies between what's happened in China GDP and in the U.S. A lot
componenttext: I know one measure that gets a lot of attention is the GDP and what happens to that growth rate and when does your business [indiscernible]  Around that. Again, I would say there's some analogies between what's happened in China GDP and in the U.S. A lot of their GDP growth is based on their government stimulus. A lot of that was incentives for people to buy specific goods and people went and did that. And I started to say similar to the U.S. but they didn't buy as much stuff that wasn't being offered an incentive. So if you look at the listed economic growth in the fourth quarter in the U.S,  [indiscernible] never greater than 5%. It didn't feel like a 5% from a consumer standpoint and I think you have the same thing right now happening in China. So we're going to look at broader measures and obviously, we're a pretty good bellwether because we're everywhere in China. So I think, well, we may see it before you see it in all the measures combined, anyway.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think David talked about our business on the economic side. The only thing is, when you look at the Chinese economy, fundamentally, it's one of the strongest in the world. So it's just a matter of when it's going to come back. We feel pretty confident t
componenttext: I think David talked about our business on the economic side. The only thing is, when you look at the Chinese economy, fundamentally, it's one of the strongest in the world. So it's just a matter of when it's going to come back. We feel pretty confident that it will. The amazing thing is, and Rick said, is that we follow the consumer confidence index, that's one we think is a pretty decent indicator. The amazing part about that is in the fourth quarter of this year, it was still down versus last year. We look at fourth quarter '09 versus fourth quarter '08. Year-over-year consumer confidence is down. It's starting to show year-over-year improvement. It looks like it. So that's a good sign. The export growth or exports turn from pretty negative most of the year to positive. So only in December. And there's a lot of people saying that's going to continue, which will definitely be good. And then also, we actually did see some improvement, as David gave you earlier the break in some of the segments of the market, that divergence between Central and West and export markets actually narrowed as the year progressed. So there's plenty of signs pointing in the right direction. It's just going to be a matter of time. And also, the Chinese consumer has always been a big saver. We all know that. We probably are a little bit more cautious. But like you said, all these signs are pointing in the right direction.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Joe Buckley with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Joe Buckley with Bank of America.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a little bit about pricing in the U.S. and pricing YRI and it sounds like you have no price now in most instances. Can you address China also where you are in pricing year-over-year? And then secondly, on the KFC U.S., you said 80% of your fran
componenttext: You talked a little bit about pricing in the U.S. and pricing YRI and it sounds like you have no price now in most instances. Can you address China also where you are in pricing year-over-year? And then secondly, on the KFC U.S., you said 80% of your franchisees are paying on time. Is 20% being late an unusually large number? How does that relate historically? And then lastly, the CapEx number for the year came in much lower than we we're thinking, about $100 million lower. Does that get pushed into 2010 or are what's sort of the story with the CapEx?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, let me answer that. On China pricing at zero, current run rate on pricing. And then on the CapEx piece, there's going to be no carryover impact to our forecast we provided you for 2010. It was just underspending across a lot of different categories.
componenttext: Joe, let me answer that. On China pricing at zero, current run rate on pricing. And then on the CapEx piece, there's going to be no carryover impact to our forecast we provided you for 2010. It was just underspending across a lot of different categories. So there wasn't anything actually in particular but was all spread across. The actively growing parts of our business, which was YRI in China. So it was just a little here and there, but it will not be something -- it wasn't necessarily timing that will be additive to 2010.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding the percentage that are laid, that number's usually below 10%. So 20% is higher than usual.
componenttext: Regarding the percentage that are laid, that number's usually below 10%. So 20% is higher than usual.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Steve West with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: When we talk about getting Taco Bell back on track and the Drive-Thru Diet and then what we've seen with the KFC Grilled Chicken maybe not performing as was expected early, maybe it's just stabilizing. How would you see kind of the difference between the
componenttext: When we talk about getting Taco Bell back on track and the Drive-Thru Diet and then what we've seen with the KFC Grilled Chicken maybe not performing as was expected early, maybe it's just stabilizing. How would you see kind of the difference between the two and maybe what we should expect as we go forward on getting Taco Bell back on track, and even getting KFC back on track here?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Taco Bell like I told you, we're very pumped up about what's going on there and we feel good about the pipeline and I think we're going to -- you will see I think a solid year. I think at KFC, our first half is going to be tough because we'll be overlappi
componenttext: Taco Bell like I told you, we're very pumped up about what's going on there and we feel good about the pipeline and I think we're going to -- you will see I think a solid year. I think at KFC, our first half is going to be tough because we'll be overlapping Kentucky Grilled Chicken, which was easily the most successful new product that was launched in the category last year. But we expect to see steady progress at KFC, and we expect each of our businesses to make more money next year this year than they made last year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Jason West with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jason West with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could talk about the percent of cash flow that you generate out of the U.S. Pizza Hut and KFC businesses? You mentioned the profits. I just wanted to see if the cash flow mix is similar as well. And also, are you having any collectio
componenttext: Just wondering if you could talk about the percent of cash flow that you generate out of the U.S. Pizza Hut and KFC businesses? You mentioned the profits. I just wanted to see if the cash flow mix is similar as well. And also, are you having any collection issues at Pizza Hut, given the weak sales we've seen there? And then third, just in terms of the refranchising, particularly KFC which has been a little slow, do you expect to sell those restaurants to existing franchisees or are you looking for third parties to come and get involved with that system?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: On the by-brand cash flow, it's pretty comparable. Probably the only thing that would be different is obviously there's higher capital expenditures at Taco Bell. So if you're looking at more of a free cash flow measure, you have that impact [indiscernible
componenttext: On the by-brand cash flow, it's pretty comparable. Probably the only thing that would be different is obviously there's higher capital expenditures at Taco Bell. So if you're looking at more of a free cash flow measure, you have that impact [indiscernible] are growing net units and there is some company investment. But otherwise, we could pretty well track what the profits probably [ph] is.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: On your question on the Pizza Hut system is that franchisees are in good shape there. They added commodity benefits in 2009, so they were making good profits even though they had soft sales. We also have larger franchisees in the Pizza Hut system that are
componenttext: On your question on the Pizza Hut system is that franchisees are in good shape there. They added commodity benefits in 2009, so they were making good profits even though they had soft sales. We also have larger franchisees in the Pizza Hut system that are generally well-capitalized. So a couple of one-sy, two-sy types of issues, but for the most part very solid on Pizza Hut side. And in general, the large franchisees, we haven't seen problems.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of David Tarantino with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of David Tarantino with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Question for Rick on the tie between the earnings growth outlook for 2010 and the comps plan that you've provided. I think at the Analyst Day, you seem to suggest that you might be able to hit the 10% EPS growth without a 2% comp. So the question is, is t
componenttext: Question for Rick on the tie between the earnings growth outlook for 2010 and the comps plan that you've provided. I think at the Analyst Day, you seem to suggest that you might be able to hit the 10% EPS growth without a 2% comp. So the question is, is that still the case? Do you think you have some room on the cost side if comps fall short? And then secondly, what level of comp decline would you start to get nervous about your ability to get to that 10% earnings growth?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: There's obviously no firm answer I could give on that. I think that there's probably no difference from where we were in December, my perspective again assumption that I've been working on here is that if you have a weaker economy than people's expectatio
componenttext: There's obviously no firm answer I could give on that. I think that there's probably no difference from where we were in December, my perspective again assumption that I've been working on here is that if you have a weaker economy than people's expectation is you probably have a bit of a natural hedge on your commodity costs. Then obviously things go the other way then we'll have the upside on the sales piece of it. So I think modest increases, decreases I don't expect a change. Anything significant, of course, you'd have to worry about. I don't have a sort of a firm number in my head. I do think that, as we should've said given the fourth quarter, we're not going to the year with momentum. So clearly, we're really cheering for the economy to pick up on our sales to pick up. So I think we're not starting with momentum. But I feel like, David, I feel good about our plans for the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned same-store sales expectation is that the growth will be back-weighted. How are you thinking about the profitability or the operating income growth. Is that also going to be back-weighted or with the cost being favorable in the first half, wo
componenttext: You mentioned same-store sales expectation is that the growth will be back-weighted. How are you thinking about the profitability or the operating income growth. Is that also going to be back-weighted or with the cost being favorable in the first half, would you expect to be more balanced?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say probably what you just said is being my best guess. Back-end weighted but not as much as the sales because we expect the commodities to be favorable in the first quarter.
componenttext: I would say probably what you just said is being my best guess. Back-end weighted but not as much as the sales because we expect the commodities to be favorable in the first quarter.

componenttext: We're in the midst now of expanding the Krushers line across KFC International. So we are adding to the line different products. This is a product that or basically as sub-brand that we will continue to add news to as we go over time. And so we're very, very enthusiastic about them.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just hoping to get a better understanding of your tax rate. I think you guided to a roughly 26% at the Analyst Day for 2010. But just looking at the model, looks like it hasn't been that high since '04. So what factors would actually lead to a higher
componenttext: I'm just hoping to get a better understanding of your tax rate. I think you guided to a roughly 26% at the Analyst Day for 2010. But just looking at the model, looks like it hasn't been that high since '04. So what factors would actually lead to a higher tax rate for you guys in 2010?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we gave a rate of 26% as we have always expect to average over the next three to eight years. It could fluctuate from year-to-year and from quarter-to-quarter as it has in the past. We benefited a lot from planning, reconciling audits with the IRS,
componenttext: Again, we gave a rate of 26% as we have always expect to average over the next three to eight years. It could fluctuate from year-to-year and from quarter-to-quarter as it has in the past. We benefited a lot from planning, reconciling audits with the IRS, et cetera, and we still expect to see benefits from those and just not quite as large over the next three years as we had over the last two.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me wrap this up. First of all, thanks to all of you on the call. As we continue to execute against our global opportunities, our business model will increasingly be driven by China, Yum! Restaurants International and Taco Bell in the U.S. The re
componenttext: Okay, let me wrap this up. First of all, thanks to all of you on the call. As we continue to execute against our global opportunities, our business model will increasingly be driven by China, Yum! Restaurants International and Taco Bell in the U.S. The restructuring of Pizza Hut and KFC in the U.S. continues, and this will ultimately improve our turns, as well as the stability and predictability of the cash flow in the U.S. business. We are very focused, very, very focused on addressing the strategic challenges of both those brands that we expect will ultimately provide upside from a profit perspective from our position that we have today. Overall, we believe that the execution of our strategies will lead us to a business model that will enable us to continue our track record of consistent performance and achieving at least 10% EPS growth each year. For 2010, we believe that all of our businesses are better off and better prepared to drive sales as the global consumer comes out as what you might characterize as a hunkered down mode. Importantly, keep in mind that more than half of our EPS growth will be driven by new units built last year and units to be opened in the next several months. In China, our business is well positioned for continued growth with its substantial infrastructure advantages, the strong brand positions I've talked about, the new unit investment returns that are as good as ever. So we are in the right place at the right time with the right brands. Yum! Restaurants International continues to drive solid growth each year and build its future runway for growth based on the strength of its broad geography, being in over 110 countries. We've got an extensive franchise growth machine and a leading position in emerging markets around the world. And in particular, we're very excited about what's going on in India and France as we highlighted at the annual conference. Finally, in the United States, we are making progress towards positioning Taco Bell as a significant growth engine, driven by both an increase in our average unit volumes, as well as the new unit growth that we expect to drive over time. With all this in mind, we continue to expect EPS growth of at least 10% for 2010, which would mark the ninth consecutive year we would meet our annual target of 10% growth. And we are confident that we will continue to build the value of our company not only in 2010 but well beyond. It's a great business and we love running it and building it and thanks for being on the call and I look forward now to talking to our employees around the world. We always have a talk to David call right after this and I can't wait to tell them about what's going on and convey the excitement that we have for 2010. Thank you very much.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
