headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Janice, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the 2010 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn today's conference
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Janice, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the 2010 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn today's conference over to Mr. Tim Jerzyk, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Thank you, Mr. Jerzyk. You may begin your conference.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Janice, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call. This call is being recorded and will be available for playback. We are broadcasting the conference call via our website www.yum.com. Please be advised that if you ask a ques
componenttext: Thank you, Janice, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on the call. This call is being recorded and will be available for playback. We are broadcasting the conference call via our website www.yum.com. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and any future use of the recording.I would also like to advise that this conference call includes forward-looking statements that reflect management’s expectations based on currently available data. However, actual results are subject to future events and uncertainties. The information in this conference call related to projections or other forward-looking statements may be relied on subject to the Safe Harbor statement included in our earnings release last night and may continue to be used while this call remains in the active portion of the company’s website at www.yum.com.In addition, we would like you to please be aware of a couple of upcoming Yum! investor events, where you'll have a great opportunity to meet leadership teams from our businesses. May 18, we will host YRI Investor Day in Dallas, followed by Pizza Hut Investor Day on May 19, also in Dallas.  Base [ph] is limited, so please notify us if you plan to attend these great events.Also on Tuesday, July 13, our second quarter earnings will be released and a conference call will follow. It will be held the next morning on July 14. On our call today, we'll hear from David Novak, Chairman and CEO; and Rick Carucci, our CFO. Following remarks from both, we will take your questions. Now I'll turn the call over to David Novak.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased that based on our strong first quarter performance, we are well on our way to achieving our ninth straight year of achieving our annual target of at least 10% EPS growth. Our first quarter worldwide ope
componenttext: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased that based on our strong first quarter performance, we are well on our way to achieving our ninth straight year of achieving our annual target of at least 10% EPS growth. Our first quarter worldwide operating profit grew by 17% and EPS increased 23%, before special items. We are particularly pleased with our business in China, which reported robust profit growth of 37%, driven by both strong unit development and same-store sales growth. In the United States, we were also pleased to see the significant sales improvement from the low point of the fourth quarter, particularly at Pizza Hut. However, U.S. profits were down 9% and same-store sales declined 1%.  At Yum! Restaurants International, we increased system sales by 1% and profits by 2% prior to foreign currency translation, primarily due to new unit development. While clearly, we have more work to do, overall, we were pleased with this start at 2010.Now let me take you through our key strategies and trends for each of our divisions. First, let's talk about China, where we continue to build leading brands in every significant restaurant category. We are particularly pleased with the performance in our China business. Same-store sales grew by 4% and units expanded 14%, while restaurant margins were at a record level of nearly 27%, all combined to generate robust profit growth of 37%. This is particularly impressive when you consider that we were lapping 30% profit growth in the first quarter of last year. New unit development continues to be the major driver of our growth, and we remain the largest U.S. retail developer in China. We opened up 96 new units this quarter, and our China new unit returns continue to be the best in our business. In terms of scale, we surpassed 3,500 units, strengthening our leading position in the world's largest growth market.KFC is our largest brand in China, with nearly 3,000 units in over 650 cities, with superior average unit volumes of $1.4 million per year. We are continuing to grow our business and leverage our assets. A key KFC initiative is delivery, which is now available in over 110 cities and nearly 1,000 units. This is proving to be a developing sales layer for us, now representing over 3% of sales. KFC breakfast is another way we are leveraging our assets, as we now have national distribution. KFC breakfast represents nearly 7% of transactions and continues to steadily grow. Importantly, KFC continues to build its leading image in China across key brand majors.Pizza Hut Casual Dining continues to be the leading western casual dining concept in China, with 467 units in 122 cities. Our new menu strategy continues to drive double-digit same-store sales growth. We offer a broad variety of entrées, including beef, chicken and rice dishes, along with appetizers, beverages and desserts. Amazingly, we are actually updating 25% of our menu every six months, with new products, to keep the concept fresh and relevant. We are having solid success, building a true casual dining concept, with everyday affordable value.We also continue to invest behind the development of our emerging brands. Pizza Hut Home Service in the Home Delivery category, now has over 100 units in 11 cities, and East Dawning, our Chinese fast food brand, continues to progress, as we drive our scalable economics.Next, Yum! Restaurants International, where our strategy is to drive aggressive expansion and build strong brands everywhere outside of China. New unit development, which like China, is a key driver of growth for this business and continued with 109 openings this quarter in more than 40 countries. Approximately 90% of this growth came from our strong network of around 1,000 franchisees. We expect to deliver our goal of adding about 900 new units for the full year. Our first-quarter same-store sales declined 1%, after adjusting for timing of Chinese New Year's. Overall, we drove 2% operating profit growth, excluding foreign currency translation for the quarter.KFC is focusing its attention on driving value around the world to build sales momentum in what remains a somewhat challenging consumer environment. We're expanding our value menu to more markets, using proven strategies that have been very successful in markets like South Africa and the United Kingdom. Additionally, we continue to build our new incremental sales layers. Our Krushers line of frozen beverages continues to expand and is now available in over 2,000 units in over 25 countries. Our KFC breakfast initiative, we call it KFC a.m., also continues to grow with nearly 400 units in four markets.Pizza Hut continues to make progress, elevating its brand offering and strengthening its position as the leading Western casual dining concept, with everyday affordable prices. While we have weaker transaction trends due to Pizza Hut's higher average guest check, we're encouraged by the progress we're making with our expanded menu, including the wider variety of appetizers, beverages, entrées and desserts.Yum! Restaurants International's new growth markets, France, India and Russia, delivered 14% system sales growth, prior to foreign currency translation this quarter. KFC France opened its 100th unit and is moving towards having the scale to ultimately have national television advertisement. We expect this will drive further brand awareness, particularly in the provincial cities. In Russia, we continue to drive sales growth in KFC ROSTIK'S units and now have over 150 units in 22 cities. Our business in India continues to perform well, with solid same-store sales growth and new unit expansion. We now have 74 KFCs in 13 cities and 159 Pizza Huts in 33 cities. KFC is now leveraging television advertising to build brand awareness and promote new products in India. Taco Bell International continues to expand with our first unit in Bangalore, India, in that country's largest mall,  Mantri Mall. You might have read in the Wall Street Journal that our initial sales at the store has been extremely strong, and transactions have actually exceeded 1,000 per day.The results from other recent openings in Spain, Dubai, Cyprus and Panama have also been very encouraging, with our stores comparably exceeding sales targets. Looking ahead, we are on track to open two new Taco Bell units in London in the second quarter and expect to open new markets like Korea, Kuwait, Peru and Colombia, later this year.Next on to our U.S. business, where our focus is to improve our brand positions, consistency and returns. As we noted in our earnings release, performance in our U.S. business for the first quarter was relatively weak, with same-store sales down 1% and operating profit down 9%. But we were pleased with the significant improvement from the fourth quarter of 2009. Pizza Hut led the way with 5% same-store sales growth, driven by the success of the "$10 any way you want it" promotion. There is no doubt America loves Pizza Hut pizzas. So this has addressed our number one problem, we were simply too expensive. And now, we're working on ways to sustain this value. Going forward, we are also striving to transform Pizza Hut from just pizza to pizza, pasta and wings. Tuscani Tuesday offers consumers Pizza Hut's pastas at a great value of $10, and Wing Wednesday offers consumers Pizza Hut's award-winning chicken wings, also at great value. Pizza Hut has clearly turned the corner on sales trends.At Taco Bell, we were disappointed with a 2% decline in same-store sales but encouraged by the fact that our transactions were positive for the quarter. We had experienced some trade down with less drink and combo incidents. Taco Bell's pipeline of products is strong for the balance of the year, focusing on value to the consumer, in a market clearly focused on everyday low prices.KFC's performance improved sequentially, but we still have our work cut out for us. We are focused on three key areas, as we turn the brand around, balanced options, featuring Kentucky Grilled Chicken, portable product innovation, like the new Double Down sandwich, made from two boneless fillets, grilled or fried, and improved operations.Overall, our U.S. performance has improved from the low point of the fourth quarter. We expect this trend to continue, especially as we move into the second half of the year, both in terms of our top line sales and profit performance. One other note. I'm sure you also noticed from our release, that we took a non-cash charge that basically reflects the beginning of refranchising KFC to 5% ownership. That is also our goal for Pizza Hut, where we've already began the journey and are well on our way.So let me wrap up the first quarter, overall, by saying, we are off to a strong start in 2010. While the global operating environment remains challenging, we are especially pleased with the strong performance in our China business and the improving trends we are seeing in our U.S. business, which we expect to continue to build, as the year progresses. We're confident we are well on our way delivering another year of at least 10% earnings per share growth, which would be our ninth year in a row of meeting or exceeding this target. Now let me turn it over to Rick Carucci, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and good morning. In this section of our call, I'm going to comment on three areas: Our first quarter results, our outlook for the business during the balance of 2010 and our strategy in emerging markets.As David mentioned, we are very e
componenttext: Thank you, David, and good morning. In this section of our call, I'm going to comment on three areas: Our first quarter results, our outlook for the business during the balance of 2010 and our strategy in emerging markets.As David mentioned, we are very excited about our first quarter results. I'm sure any CFO will tell you that they would much prefer a strong start than having to play catch-up.As we review a few of our highlights, let's start with China. We had a very strong Chinese New Year holiday. This led to first quarter system sales growth of 15%, including same-store sales growth of 4%. Sales were solid across the country, including the high export regions. While we are not yet ready to say that the Chinese consumer has fully recovered, we are starting to see signs that the consumer environment is improving. As an example, consumer confidence in China has increased year-over-year, the last three months.A big driver of sales continues to be our development results in China. New-unit economics remains strong, and we expect that we will continue to expand broadly across China. Our profit growth of 37% was also driven by record first quarter margins, as we benefited significantly from chicken cost deflation versus prior year and lower-than-trend wage inflation.Now on to Yum! Restaurants International. Overall, our sales results were relatively weak in our large developed markets like Japan and Canada, as well as equity businesses like Australia and Mexico. These markets dampened the overall sales results for YRI in the quarter. The good news is that YRI still benefited from broad-based new-unit development of 3% in the first quarter. However, this led to only 2% profit growth prior to currency translation. We did benefit from a $14 million ForEx upside in the first quarter, which resulted in YRI reported profit growth of 13%. Next in the U.S., we continued to battle high unemployment and industry focus on value. However, our U.S. business realized significantly better sales performance than we saw in the fourth quarter.On the whole, our U.S. restaurant margin declined 90 basis points versus prior year, primarily due to the decline in same-store sales. Commodity deflation of $5 million was offset by a modest impact from sales mix shift. For example, Taco Bell experienced the higher mix on the Why Pay More menu and had lower drink incidents.While trying to improve our value offerings, we also managed our business with tight cost management. In the U.S., we reduced our G&A by $6 million. When you pull it all together, we were pleased with where we stand after the first quarter.Now let me share with you some of our thoughts for the remainder of 2010. We expect our second quarter sales dynamics to be similar to the first quarter for our divisions. We expect moderate same-store sales growth in China in the second quarter. For the U.S., in the second half of the year, we expect positive sales growth. A key reason is that our comparisons versus prior year gets significantly easier. Remember, we're lapping at second half,  where U.S. sales were down 7% in 2009. We do not expect China's exceptional margin performance in the first quarter to continue. We expect some commodity inflation in the back half of the year, and we also forecast greater impact from wage inflation. Wage inflation was lower than normal in 2009 and is significantly picking up again in 2010. For the full year, we expect moderate year-over-year margin improvement over last year's 21% margins in mainland China.Our after-tax results in the second quarter will be challenged, as we roll over a 16.4% effective tax rate before special items from the second quarter of 2009. Special items are very difficult to predict and can be quite lumpy. However, this year, it appears that we have more downsides than upsides. During the first quarter, we took a special-items charge that included a $56 million expense from U.S. refranchising. This includes gains from the sale of 46 restaurants sold in the first quarter. This also reflects that we floated for sale, a significant number of KFC U.S. company units. Our accounting policy is to recognize a non-cash write off for potential losses from refranchising when units are offered for sale.In the second quarter, we will also lap a $68 million one-time non-cash gain in 2009 related to increasing our ownership in the KFC Shanghai joint venture. Overall, as David said, we are confident we're on track to meeting our objective of at least 10% earnings per share growth.As we've shared with you before, one of Yum!'s unique strengths is our presence in emerging markets. Today, I'd like to give you a few more insights into this significant growth opportunity. Emerging markets, as defined by World Bank's guidelines, generally includes countries whose gross national income per capita is less than $12,000. This group includes countries like China, Indonesia, Malaysia, India, Russia, Vietnam and Brazil, all of which have near over 100 Yum! restaurants. The good news is that collectively, these emerging markets are growing their economies at a fast rate. With the booming middle-class population in emerging markets, we strongly believe there's a long runway for restaurant growth in those countries. As you may recall, I talked about our penetration of three units per million people internationally, versus the 60 units per million we have in the U.S. Further, in the top 10 emerging markets, we currently have 1.5 units per million people. These demonstrate that we are clearly, on the ground floor of this huge growth opportunity. Today, we have nearly 10,000 units in the emerging markets, or roughly 55% of our total YRI and China units. We are the largest restaurant company in emerging markets, and we are growing at a faster rate than our major QSR competition. For the five-year period ending in 2009, we added about 4,000 net new units in these markets, a 12% compound annual growth rate. This compares to a 1% compound annual growth rate in the balance of our international operations.As another benchmark, we currently have almost 2x the number of emerging market units as McDonald's. And we've added more net units than McDonald's at a 3:1 rate during the past five years. And here's another important point, most of our competitors aren't even trying to open restaurants in many of these emerging markets. Our experience is that it usually takes about 10 years to get to 100 units in a new country. This is a point at which you could begin to scale a concept, as you have a proven consumer proposition, a more efficient supply chain and access to mass media such as television. Overall, for emerging markets, Yum! enjoys a combination of an existing lead in penetration, a higher growth rate and the knowledge of the lead times it would take others to have a meaningful presence in these markets.  This provides Yum! with an opportunity to increase our competitive advantage that will likely last for a very long time. In the upcoming calls and investor meetings, we plan to provide more color commentary around our growth opportunities in emerging markets. In summary, given our plans and our first quarter results, we believe Yum! is well positioned to, once again, deliver solid financial performance in 2010. At the same time, we're equally excited about the foundation we are building in emerging markets to drive strong performance for many years to come. Back to you David.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Rick. And let's open it up for Q&A.
componenttext: Thank you very much, Rick. And let's open it up for Q&A.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Jeff Omohundro with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Jeff Omohundro with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I just had two questions on the Domestic business. First on, the Pizza Hut value effort, I wonder if you'd give a little more color on the impact on check and mix with the $10 promo. And given the response, do you think it will extend the LTO beyond origi
componenttext: I just had two questions on the Domestic business. First on, the Pizza Hut value effort, I wonder if you'd give a little more color on the impact on check and mix with the $10 promo. And given the response, do you think it will extend the LTO beyond original plan? How are you thinking about sustaining value there, going forward?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, as you know, we posted strong sales in the first quarter 5%, and the promotion has been very successful. And the reason as it addressed, our biggest problem, which is value. I think, that what we've seen is that our comparable margins have hel
componenttext: Well, Jeff, as you know, we posted strong sales in the first quarter 5%, and the promotion has been very successful. And the reason as it addressed, our biggest problem, which is value. I think, that what we've seen is that our comparable margins have held steady, as we've had this sales slip and we've had  strong flow through, which has offset a lot of the price discounting that we typically have had with this promotion, obviously. And the good news for us is that the brand metrics has really helped solid, so the brand is, in fact, improving, in terms of its consumer perspective. So what we're doing right now is we're looking and working very hard with our franchisees on ways to sustain our everyday value proposition. And the franchisees are very committed to this. They've seen the turnaround in the business and the power of making our brand more affordable and accessible to the vast majority of customers.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, just regarding your question on check, check was down close to about 10%. But transactions increased at a much faster rate than that.
componenttext: And Jeff, just regarding your question on check, check was down close to about 10%. But transactions increased at a much faster rate than that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And my other question was on Taco Bell. How are you assessing the consumer response to the Pacific Shrimp Taco? I'm asking this because of the new protein efforts there, and should we expect to see more efforts along those lines?
componenttext: And my other question was on Taco Bell. How are you assessing the consumer response to the Pacific Shrimp Taco? I'm asking this because of the new protein efforts there, and should we expect to see more efforts along those lines?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, that the consumer response to the product has been very good. People like the product itself, and we actually have some product supply issues, because the Shrimp Tacos basically flew off the shelf. So I think, it's the first time we ever had a fi
componenttext: I think, that the consumer response to the product has been very good. People like the product itself, and we actually have some product supply issues, because the Shrimp Tacos basically flew off the shelf. So I think, it's the first time we ever had a fish product during Lent, which made a lot of sense. So I think you will see that on a targeted in-and-out basis, as we go forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on China. I was wondering if you can give more granularity on your thoughts on what's happening in the consumer environment? You mentioned you're not ready to call a recovery in the Chinese consumer, yet your results were pretty strong in t
componenttext: My question is on China. I was wondering if you can give more granularity on your thoughts on what's happening in the consumer environment? You mentioned you're not ready to call a recovery in the Chinese consumer, yet your results were pretty strong in the quarter. So my question is what's giving you pause on calling for that recovery?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at China, we look at a bunch of different measures from an economic standpoint. One of the things I highlighted in my speech is one of the things we look at is consumer confidence. That's gone up the last three months, which is good. But
componenttext: Yes, when we look at China, we look at a bunch of different measures from an economic standpoint. One of the things I highlighted in my speech is one of the things we look at is consumer confidence. That's gone up the last three months, which is good. But it's still below what it would've been probably about a year, a year and a half ago. So we still have ways for it to go. You're starting to see exports rise as well. Local governments are confident enough to start to increase wages again at a pretty high rate, which puts us on the margin side with indication that the people are starting to feel more bullish about the economy. You still have the push towards essentially in West, that we've talked about before, and those economies are still doing a bit better than the coastal economies, and we'll continue to move some of our development in that direction. But I'd say it's better than it was, but not what it was, let's say, before things started going South.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing anything since the close of your first quarter that would suggest that type of load and that single digit comp would not be sustainable for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Are you seeing anything since the close of your first quarter that would suggest that type of load and that single digit comp would not be sustainable for the rest of the year?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we sort of said is for the second quarter, we expect similar types of numbers. And we call something out of it, it's a significant difference. We haven't seen a significant change since the first quarter. So it was not the last time, we called
componenttext: Well, what we sort of said is for the second quarter, we expect similar types of numbers. And we call something out of it, it's a significant difference. We haven't seen a significant change since the first quarter. So it was not the last time, we called out Pizza Hut. But we don't call out a couple of points up or down.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer with UBS.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question about the U.S. business. Just a little general question, I mean, obviously the profit for that first quarter was down significantly. You're not going to get any favors from food cost from this point forward as much -- there migh
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question about the U.S. business. Just a little general question, I mean, obviously the profit for that first quarter was down significantly. You're not going to get any favors from food cost from this point forward as much -- there might have been a trend in sales that makes you feel better. But obviously, the starting point in terms of trends and on profit was not exactly a great one. How do you feel? What's the feeling about this U.S. business profit like for the year? Obviously, we're not up pertaining [ph] guidance is what you're saying [ph]. Any comments would be helpful.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to put some of the sales and profits and commodities and inflation in perspective, we -- remember what I put in my speech is our overlaps gets significantly easier in the second half of the year. So we're not necessarily assuming a great economic rec
componenttext: Just to put some of the sales and profits and commodities and inflation in perspective, we -- remember what I put in my speech is our overlaps gets significantly easier in the second half of the year. So we're not necessarily assuming a great economic recovery for ourselves to get better. We start lapping minus 7% in the second half of 2009. So we're still running the business as if things are going to be pretty tight with the consumer, and things are better than they were for us, obviously, in the third quarter or fourth quarter last year. But we still have several ways to go before we're going to say there's an economic recovery in the U.S. On the commodity side, we had a little bit of commodity deflation in the first quarter. Our current guess is it will be about flat for the full year. So we don't see a huge difference there. So we'll continue to try to do what we do in these types of times. It's one, we have value initiatives, two, try to have some great product initiatives, because, obviously, you need to have innovation as well. And then we'll manage across three types of -- we're looking at both productivity initiatives at all our brands. And I think the teams have done a pretty good job of managing those costs. In terms of the profits in the first quarter, our overall sales were down 1%. Our company sales we're down 2%. So that's probably why the profits, if you put that in perspective, is really why we were down 9%. So given the minus 2% in company, that's pretty much what we would have expected to be, given that sales level.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think, David, in the end, as we look at how it all adds up, we're still comfortable with saying that we can grow our profits 5% in the U.S.
componenttext: And I think, David, in the end, as we look at how it all adds up, we're still comfortable with saying that we can grow our profits 5% in the U.S.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the Pizza category in the U.S.? Who do you think you're taking share from? And how sustainable do you think that's going to be over the next few quarters?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the Pizza category in the U.S.? Who do you think you're taking share from? And how sustainable do you think that's going to be over the next few quarters?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, what we've done is we've made ourselves much more competitive on the pricing front and that's we're seeing our gains coming -- usually when we grow like we're growing right now, it comes from the overall category and the mom and pops.
componenttext: Well, I think, what we've done is we've made ourselves much more competitive on the pricing front and that's we're seeing our gains coming -- usually when we grow like we're growing right now, it comes from the overall category and the mom and pops.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think, over the next few quarters, this could be sustainable? Or do you think you've seen some marketing and more exposure by consumers to good promotions and maybe that sizzles out? Or do you think that's going to be a sustainable...
componenttext: And do you think, over the next few quarters, this could be sustainable? Or do you think you've seen some marketing and more exposure by consumers to good promotions and maybe that sizzles out? Or do you think that's going to be a sustainable...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, the category has always been enormously competitive, especially on the pricing front. And I think, that the fact that we're being more competitive on the pricing front today helped us. And the fact that the system's committed to that, means that
componenttext: I think, the category has always been enormously competitive, especially on the pricing front. And I think, that the fact that we're being more competitive on the pricing front today helped us. And the fact that the system's committed to that, means that we should have more sustainability on our overall brand over time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Farmer with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Farmer with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: You guys have been running without menu pricing in China for at least six months, according to my model. What's the opportunity in coming quarters, especially if you expect to see some inflation in the back half of 2010?
componenttext: You guys have been running without menu pricing in China for at least six months, according to my model. What's the opportunity in coming quarters, especially if you expect to see some inflation in the back half of 2010?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: We're obviously looking at that now. We're trying to balance. Again, as we sort of said before, the Chinese consumers still soft. We had, obviously, a very favorable first quarter, because as we mentioned, labor was unusually low, costs were unusually low
componenttext: We're obviously looking at that now. We're trying to balance. Again, as we sort of said before, the Chinese consumers still soft. We had, obviously, a very favorable first quarter, because as we mentioned, labor was unusually low, costs were unusually low. So we'll have to look at that. But the good news is we got some very positive profits going into that timeframe. But we're studying what we want to do now for the back half of the year. But we're not going to do anything at least for the next several months.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason West with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason West with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wonder if you could update us on the KFC business in the U.S. Last quarter, you talked about that some of the franchisees were behind in making royalty payments. You guys had a fairly sizable chart there. I didn't see one of those this quarter if t
componenttext: I just wonder if you could update us on the KFC business in the U.S. Last quarter, you talked about that some of the franchisees were behind in making royalty payments. You guys had a fairly sizable chart there. I didn't see one of those this quarter if there's some improvement you're seeing there. And then talk about the likelihood that you get a big transaction done or multiple transactions done on the refranchising side, as well as the success of the new product you just launched.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: On that side, we're going to keep our eye on that. It actually did a little better in the first quarter, so our receivables are better. And hopefully, we'd get into a higher seasonals time, as the year gets over. So keeping our eye on that, but probably,
componenttext: On that side, we're going to keep our eye on that. It actually did a little better in the first quarter, so our receivables are better. And hopefully, we'd get into a higher seasonals time, as the year gets over. So keeping our eye on that, but probably, a bit better than we were in the fourth quarter. Regarding refranchising, just to put that into context, again, for people who may not be as familiar, we run a three-year refranchising program that really started in the beginning of '08. And our goal was to go from over 20% of our U.S. restaurants, or company-owned to about 10%, which, as David said, about 5% at the KFC and Pizza Hut level. In the first two years of that, we finished Long John Silver's refranchising.  As David said, we're well on our way on Pizza Hut. And we think we'll be close to finishing that within  the original three-year time frame, which would've ended in 2010. And then what we said in December is that we're behind on KFC. We started late on KFC, and therefore, we think the total program will take a bit longer than we originally thought. So KFC, we just really started in earnest this quarter in terms of loading deals. So we'll have to see how -- we have a lot of work to do on that stuff. We're still just hearing from potential buyers. So we have a long way to go on that side, but we're going after it. So we now think it's the right time to market. We think the brand is performing better than it was a while back. And we were really excited about some of the product initiatives that we have done and that we are going to do going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Just from an overall business perspective, KFC continues to be our biggest challenge. In the second quarter, we'll likely be negative as we overlap last year's successful Kentucky Grilled Chicken launch. However, we've got some really good programs includ
componenttext: Just from an overall business perspective, KFC continues to be our biggest challenge. In the second quarter, we'll likely be negative as we overlap last year's successful Kentucky Grilled Chicken launch. However, we've got some really good programs including the launch of the Double Down sandwich, which we just introduced. And we have a pink bucket promotion coming up where we donate $0.50 of every bucket sold to fight breast cancer, which we feel very good about as well. As we move forward, we're really focused on more innovation around portable products and high-end offerings. So we're going to leverage both our grilled and fried and boneless offerings as we go forward. So for the full year, we expect to see improvements in sales and definitely, more profitability as we go forward. The other thing we're very focused on and passionate about -- and Roger Eaton is leading the charge on this at KFC, is that we're improving operations because we see that definitely as our single biggest opportunity to drive sustainable same-store sales growth. So there's a lot of work going on right now. We put our best leaders that we have around the company. We brought in a lot of talent at KFC. We're totally passionate towards turning around the U.S. business. And I'm really proud of the efforts that are going on. But there's a lot of wood to chop, so to speak.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: My first question one is on YRI. Can you just walk through a couple of the key markets there and why you think your sales has remained somewhat soft, for example, the Australian market? Maybe a little commentary on the UK as well please.
componenttext: My first question one is on YRI. Can you just walk through a couple of the key markets there and why you think your sales has remained somewhat soft, for example, the Australian market? Maybe a little commentary on the UK as well please.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think YRI in Australia has had a real strong run, a great track record of consistency. And frankly, I think we fall a little bit behind on the pipeline and the innovation that we typically had coming out of Australia. And so we expect that busines
componenttext: Well, I think YRI in Australia has had a real strong run, a great track record of consistency. And frankly, I think we fall a little bit behind on the pipeline and the innovation that we typically had coming out of Australia. And so we expect that business to perform better, and it should. The brand is very strong there, and we have tremendous opportunity to keep going as well. In the UK, we're very pleased with the progress that we've made with KFC. KFC had an outstanding year last year in the United Kingdom where we were up double digits in sales and profits. And the KFC business is beginning to build some momentum there. Pizza Hut is our big challenge there. We're in the midst of really trying to transform and turn that brand around to become a stronger affordable, casual dining entry or competitor. And I think we're really more in the early days of really making a substantial change there. The team's on it, but we've got more work to do.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And just as it relates to the inflation that your expecting in commodities and wages in China, can you maybe quantify what kind of increases you'd expect in the back half? And even this quarter with a 4% comp increase, that looks like you de-levered thing
componenttext: And just as it relates to the inflation that your expecting in commodities and wages in China, can you maybe quantify what kind of increases you'd expect in the back half? And even this quarter with a 4% comp increase, that looks like you de-levered things like payroll and occupancy. So would what kind of comp do you need this year in China in order to offset those increases in those fixed costs?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of the wages, just a background again as we had -- first of all, we had some good labor initiatives from the productivity side in China in 2009. And then in the second half of 2009 in particular, the government really the -- in the local be
componenttext: Well, in terms of the wages, just a background again as we had -- first of all, we had some good labor initiatives from the productivity side in China in 2009. And then in the second half of 2009 in particular, the government really the -- in the local because this is mostly local governments -- really didn't take up minimum wages. They had very small increases in minimum wages. So in the first half of this year, we're benefiting from that. Then like I said, we're going to get hit with this probably harder than normal in the second half of the year. So we sort of said, as you know, we [ph] (50:40) increased versus prior year in the first quarter, 2.5 margin points. What we said for the full year is we have a moderate increase. So in terms of sales, we don't have an exact sales numbers that we need. They're probably modest same-store sales growth in order to deliver that kind of margin improvement for the full year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Are we just going up at double-digit rates right now or do you expect them to this year? What's the order of magnitude of wage increase do you think?
componenttext: Are we just going up at double-digit rates right now or do you expect them to this year? What's the order of magnitude of wage increase do you think?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what's happening is we benefited, as I said, in the first part of the year, we had lower than normal. So normally, wages in China, if you go over about a four-year period there in the 8% to 10% level. We actually had rates lower than that in
componenttext: Well, I think what's happening is we benefited, as I said, in the first part of the year, we had lower than normal. So normally, wages in China, if you go over about a four-year period there in the 8% to 10% level. We actually had rates lower than that in the first half of this year and I expected it to be higher than that at the balance of the year. So I bet it'd probably average about 10% or so for the full year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Senatore from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Senatore from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: First on pizza. I think you said that you thought that your share gains were coming from independents maybe. I mean all of the publicly-traded pizza delivery guys reported actually big improvements in comps. So I guess at some point, those share gains hav
componenttext: First on pizza. I think you said that you thought that your share gains were coming from independents maybe. I mean all of the publicly-traded pizza delivery guys reported actually big improvements in comps. So I guess at some point, those share gains have to level up. So I was just wondering is there any other place that you can get the market growth so almost I think [ph] (52:20) actually, one of your competitors said that the market has been in decline for something like 10 years. And now yes, it's actually turning positive. So I'm just trying to figure out again if there's the sort of sustainability. So that's the one follow-up, and then I have another on China.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I think one of the big things you have in marketing, as you guys all know, is there's nothing like the power of having the leading brand with the leading image. And where you're value competitive, your odds of success are much better. So this has always b
componenttext: I think one of the big things you have in marketing, as you guys all know, is there's nothing like the power of having the leading brand with the leading image. And where you're value competitive, your odds of success are much better. So this has always been a slug-it-out, a very competitive share game and category. What we're trying to do is have a twofold strategy. One is to be much more competitive in the pizza world, which we've done. And the real challenge that we have now is to drive sustainable everyday value as we go in the future. And the team's working very hard on how to how to stay competitive on the value front because we've seen the real power of it. But the other thing we're trying to do is that we have a tremendous opportunity to leverage our assets with the variety that we've invested in, in the last couple of years. For us, that means establishing the pasta occasion and the wing occasion as separate and distinct occasions for Pizza Hut and marketing them primarily during the week so that we'd leverage the asset that we have. So our strategy is to fight it out for share in the pizza category, leverage on our leadership and our competitive value and then leverage the asset that is definitely underutilized at Pizza Hut through the variety that we've created, the pasta and the wings and by really going after the earlier-week occasion.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on China, just wanted an update on the new unit volumes versus existing insofar as there was -- obviously, you did 4% comps, 14% unit growth. And your total system-wide sales gross was less than the sum of that. So are we still looking at so
componenttext: And then just on China, just wanted an update on the new unit volumes versus existing insofar as there was -- obviously, you did 4% comps, 14% unit growth. And your total system-wide sales gross was less than the sum of that. So are we still looking at sort of a $200,000 difference in new unit volumes? And can you talk about what the ramp is generally for units as they come online? Just apples-to-apples, is a new unit lower volume than what it may be in your two or three?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and generally we've been at this trend for a few years now, which is -- and our average unit volumes are about 1.4 million, and new units coming around 1 million, 1.1 million, right? So we're at about a $300,000 gap versus a new unit. And that trend'
componenttext: Yes, and generally we've been at this trend for a few years now, which is -- and our average unit volumes are about 1.4 million, and new units coming around 1 million, 1.1 million, right? So we're at about a $300,000 gap versus a new unit. And that trend's been going on for a while. And part of that as we going to smaller cities where we have a little bit more influence [ph] (55:20) as we are developing into existing cities. And that's the reason why there are lower sales levels. We sort of said before as you get to the smaller cities, the good news is even with the those lower sales, our margins are similar because our cost structures are lower there. In terms of ramp up, it's hard because we have so many new units that are coming in on top of each other. But our sales rates are generally a bit higher in these smaller cities as we open. So they'll tend to grow at a higher rate in the first, let's say, four or five years than the general cities would.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays Capital.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: One, just the U.S. business. We haven't talked much about Taco Bell. I think you said you were somewhat disappointed with the down 2% comps. Just wondering whether you could talk a little bit more about -- I think you said this was kind of a new trend of
componenttext: One, just the U.S. business. We haven't talked much about Taco Bell. I think you said you were somewhat disappointed with the down 2% comps. Just wondering whether you could talk a little bit more about -- I think you said this was kind of a new trend of people skewing towards the Why Pay More and perhaps less drink incidents. Just wondering whether you could talk about is that specific to Taco Bell and what the impact has been from the competitive discounting, kind of jumping in to Taco Bell's kind of more discounted push, just trying to size up the Taco Bell business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we'll always be disappointed with any kind of negative same-store sales growth. So clearly, we were down 2% in the first quarter. As you know, the overall industry trends have been negative since June of '09, and we do have the stronge
componenttext: Well, first of all, we'll always be disappointed with any kind of negative same-store sales growth. So clearly, we were down 2% in the first quarter. As you know, the overall industry trends have been negative since June of '09, and we do have the strongest value position in the category. What we saw in the first quarter was that our transactions were positive, but we did have a lower average guest check, less drinks and combo meals. And we also had -- most of our media spend was on the value, the $0.89 Beefy Five-Layer Burrito. So we did have the Why Pay More usage increase to about 20% of our mix versus the 15% of the mix. So this is what we were able to, obviously, maintain. Perhaps, we haven't seen the research yet [ph] (57:35) even four or five the value position, which we know is going to be really essential as we go forward. And we were doing it. We're able to do it in a competitive category where basically, you point out the issue more and more people are at the low end. What we really are pleased about is that we had positive transactions. So more people are coming into Taco Bell this year than last year so we can build off of that strength. Our biggest challenge is to get same-store sales growing again at Taco Bell. We're obviously happy that transactions picked up, but it's much easier to build your sales off positive transactions. So we believe as we look at our programs and our initiatives that our value and our innovation's strong enough for us to get modest same-store sales growth for the balance of the year. And as we pointed out at the analyst meeting that we had in New York, we're also extremely enthusiastic about the results we're getting from our more longer-term initiatives: Breakfast, home meal replacement, beverages. These big sales layers, we have we have a lot of big ideas in test that we are feeling better and better about as we go forward. So we're very optimistic about the future of this brand. We think we can get modest same-store sales growth to about [ph] (59:00) balance of the year. But it's slug-it-out. I mean it's definitely a slug-it-out category right now. What we're most excited about is just the long-term prospects of Taco Bell where we begin to add some of these sales layers that we're talking about that we think can actually help us become a net new unit developer of the Taco Bell. So brand's moving along, competing well in a very tough category with all kinds of upside.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a question as it relates to China, the positive 4% comp. I know last quarter, you were hesitant to really call much in the way of trends in China just because of the whole New Year's shift. And with that now behind us, I think you said the New Ye
componenttext: And just a question as it relates to China, the positive 4% comp. I know last quarter, you were hesitant to really call much in the way of trends in China just because of the whole New Year's shift. And with that now behind us, I think you said the New Year's shift was pretty strong. Are you able to size up how much of that 4% came from New Year's and kind of otherwise assess the underlying trend? Or you really can't even take a stab out of it until we get another couple of months?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really hard to. And that's why we've sort of said before and I still believe that we'll have a better handle as we get through this quarter than in  Chinese New Year. We had a very strong holiday, and so that was a good sign. But we haven't seen
componenttext: Yes, it's really hard to. And that's why we've sort of said before and I still believe that we'll have a better handle as we get through this quarter than in  Chinese New Year. We had a very strong holiday, and so that was a good sign. But we haven't seen it. Yes, we just need a longer period of time before we could judge beyond that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JP Morgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to revisit YRI and the sales performance over the last couple of quarters. And I guess we don't have a lot of data points. But you look at results like out of Domino's, out of the McDonald's, even out of Starbucks, for example. And their internat
componenttext: I wanted to revisit YRI and the sales performance over the last couple of quarters. And I guess we don't have a lot of data points. But you look at results like out of Domino's, out of the McDonald's, even out of Starbucks, for example. And their international results are much better from a same-store sales perspective even if they are developing units in certain markets. So I mean can you just kind of go back to YRI and talk about -- I think you mentioned kind of getting back on the new product pipeline in Australia. But if there's anything that's really going to change from a management perspective in terms of core competencies like product development, advertising, operations maybe even remodels, I mean if there's something that you think really needs to be redone in that marketplace is kind of the first part. Then secondly, looking at those company store margins and YRI, they continue to be under pressure. And last year it was evidently because commodity prices were contracted at the wrong time, but we're not really seeing relief in margins overall there. So if you can just focus on company store margins and the YRI division as well.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: All right, John. Meanwhile, there's no question that YRI is off to a slow start with comps down 2%, and we've got work to do to regain our sales. So you point out the issue and, definitely, we're on the case. We're focusing on value primarily in developed
componenttext: All right, John. Meanwhile, there's no question that YRI is off to a slow start with comps down 2%, and we've got work to do to regain our sales. So you point out the issue and, definitely, we're on the case. We're focusing on value primarily in developed markets given the tough environment. What we're doing is we're taking a lot of the know-how that we now have on permanent value menus from the success of like a market like in South Africa, which is we have a street-wise menu, and we're expanding that successfully into the U.K. where it now has like 14% of the mix and a significant amount of incremental sales. We're also revisiting our core signature items with new insights on products that are very unique in the marketplace, our Twister and our Zinger sandwiches for example. And we've also put together an initiative where we're launching regional successes from the past into new markets like the Wrapstar sandwich fillers and Hot Rod (sic) [Hot Rods] teaser promotions that have done well in other markets that we're moving into new markets. So we're trying to roll out and expand the proven winners into more geographies. We also are continuing the rollout of new incremental sales layers. So Krushers, which is our line of frozen beverages, is now in 2,000 units, and we're shooting to have it to 4,000 units by the end of the year. So we expect that to give us a bit of a lift [ph] (1:03:05). And we're hopeful that we'll see a better second half in 2010. Our first half lap was plus 4% in sales and the second half is minus 1%. So we're hopeful that with the initiatives we've got going, we'll be able to see better performance in YRI. So we're definitely on the case. I think the team, our management is working on the right things, and we're going to make progress.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Regarding your question on the margins, John, that's pretty much driven by where we had sales weakness and strengths. To your point, is not really driven by commodities. Commodities, we haven't had the shifts in YRI that we've had in the U.S. or Chin
componenttext: Yes. Regarding your question on the margins, John, that's pretty much driven by where we had sales weakness and strengths. To your point, is not really driven by commodities. Commodities, we haven't had the shifts in YRI that we've had in the U.S. or China over the last two years. So as we said before, they're relatively flat. So a couple of our businesses like Pizza Hut U.K., as David said in his speech and comments, has been underperforming, and that hurt our overall YRI margins. And Pizza Hut in the U.K. is higher transaction businesses when the economy's a little soft. Our experience is they usually suffer a little bit more. So the margins pretty much followed the sales in this case. So Australia is an equity business. As David said, it isn't performing as well as normal. And you saw that in the release. So that's also hurts us on the margin side. So Australia and Pizza Hut U.K. are two of the countries that brought the margin down in the first quarter.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of that Value Menu, I mean how significant will that be across the YRI in 2010? I mean what's the planning of some of that? It's in Value Menu.
componenttext: And in terms of that Value Menu, I mean how significant will that be across the YRI in 2010? I mean what's the planning of some of that? It's in Value Menu.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to quantify because in general, we've been doing value for a while. So quite a few countries already have sort of a Value Menu. So what they're trying to do is to bring those lines to other markets. And it's done sequentially, so it's not like w
componenttext: It's hard to quantify because in general, we've been doing value for a while. So quite a few countries already have sort of a Value Menu. So what they're trying to do is to bring those lines to other markets. And it's done sequentially, so it's not like we have a launch of Value July 1. A lot of countries have already had it. We're introducing it into more countries as we speak. So there's not an event that we could really quantify easily.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Buckley with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Buckley with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: In China, is there any natural advantage to the New Year falling in February as opposed to January? Or is it kind of immaterial which month it falls in?
componenttext: In China, is there any natural advantage to the New Year falling in February as opposed to January? Or is it kind of immaterial which month it falls in?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that doesn't really matter that much. It's just more a function of -- we have to lap the [ph] (1:05:45) in terms of outside of China YRI because sometimes it falls in the quarter, out of the quarter. But we haven't really seen anything dramatic in sh
componenttext: Yes, that doesn't really matter that much. It's just more a function of -- we have to lap the [ph] (1:05:45) in terms of outside of China YRI because sometimes it falls in the quarter, out of the quarter. But we haven't really seen anything dramatic in shifts between January and February.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And the plus 4% in mainland China, were transactions up more than that? Was check actually down or would check would be flattish and transactions up around 4%?
componenttext: And the plus 4% in mainland China, were transactions up more than that? Was check actually down or would check would be flattish and transactions up around 4%?

componenttextpreview: I don't have the exact numbers but similar. Transactions would've been similar to sales.
componenttext: I don't have the exact numbers but similar. Transactions would've been similar to sales.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly, there was some story I was reading about, some Internet coupon deal that kind of went wrong in China. Is that anything to be concerned about or is that kind of a minor bump on the road?
componenttext: And lastly, there was some story I was reading about, some Internet coupon deal that kind of went wrong in China. Is that anything to be concerned about or is that kind of a minor bump on the road?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We made a couponing error and caused some concern with some customers. We apologized for doing that. It's a short-term issue.
componenttext: Yes. We made a couponing error and caused some concern with some customers. We apologized for doing that. It's a short-term issue.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: And then two questions on healthcare. Rick, any sense of the cost for Yum? And then any push back from franchisees in terms of buying units with the prospect of higher healthcare costs out in the not-so-distant future?
componenttext: And then two questions on healthcare. Rick, any sense of the cost for Yum? And then any push back from franchisees in terms of buying units with the prospect of higher healthcare costs out in the not-so-distant future?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Joe, this year we anticipate a small impact of about $6 million for the loss of a tax deduction for retiring medical benefits. The major impact of this legislation will hit in 2014. And with our anticipated ownership change -- you know we're going t
componenttext: Well, Joe, this year we anticipate a small impact of about $6 million for the loss of a tax deduction for retiring medical benefits. The major impact of this legislation will hit in 2014. And with our anticipated ownership change -- you know we're going to a 5% ownership with Pizza Hut and KFC by 2014, we think it's going to cost Yum! about $20 million to $30 million based on the existing workforce structure that we anticipate. So as you know, there's a lot of legislative details to be ironed out in the next couple of years. The real challenge is that this is going to be about $10,000 to $15,000 per store cost to our franchisees beginning in 2014. And we're going to work with them to mitigate the costs. So we've got plenty of time, I think, to deal with the issue. But it certainly is an issue, and I think all of this is well understood by any franchisee who would be purchasing stores.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to ask a question about Taco Bell. So we've walked through the topline initiatives. And early in the call, you talked about how some of the domestic margins' impact came from de-leverage of Taco Bell.  I wanted to ask if you could give a little bit
componenttext: I want to ask a question about Taco Bell. So we've walked through the topline initiatives. And early in the call, you talked about how some of the domestic margins' impact came from de-leverage of Taco Bell.  I wanted to ask if you could give a little bit more detail on the status and opportunity behind the four-wall cost save initiative [ph] (1:08:35) at Taco Bell that Greg Creed laid out at the December analyst day. So any detail on the status and opportunity there would be appreciated.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: Keith, they've actively implemented all of those things, so you're seeing that. You saw that part of the result of that last year, and you're seeing the continuing benefit now.
componenttext: Keith, they've actively implemented all of those things, so you're seeing that. You saw that part of the result of that last year, and you're seeing the continuing benefit now.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-15-2010
componenttextpreview: The charge for the KFC units that are looking to be re-franchised, was this for all of the units like all 600 that you helped to re-franchise? Was this just a portion? And if just a portion, roughly how many was discharged in relation to -- how many units
componenttext: The charge for the KFC units that are looking to be re-franchised, was this for all of the units like all 600 that you helped to re-franchise? Was this just a portion? And if just a portion, roughly how many was discharged in relation to -- how many units?
