And then my second question is, on Pizza Hut and the positioning regarding value, how do you see transitioning from the $10 pizza promo? Or is this, do you think, more of a longer-term, repositioning towards greater delivery of value to consumers?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Rick on the forex question. On our balance of the year forecast, we're assuming some upside in China from forex in about the $10 million range. We expect about a $5 million negative in YRI for the balance of the year. So when you add that up, we f
componenttext: This is Rick on the forex question. On our balance of the year forecast, we're assuming some upside in China from forex in about the $10 million range. We expect about a $5 million negative in YRI for the balance of the year. So when you add that up, we figure about $5 million positive in the balance of the year. I'll let David handle the Pizza Hut value question.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, as you know, we've had a dramatic turnaround in transactions and same-store sales growth since we launched the $10 anyway you want it large pizzas. Same-store sales growth were up 8% in the second quarter. So it's been a great success for us b
componenttext: Well, Jeff, as you know, we've had a dramatic turnaround in transactions and same-store sales growth since we launched the $10 anyway you want it large pizzas. Same-store sales growth were up 8% in the second quarter. So it's been a great success for us because what we've basically done by doing this is we addressed the single biggest problem that we've had. And frankly, in our history, we've always been perceived to be the most expensive pizzas. So now we've made our products, our pizzas very affordable, and the consumer response has been overwhelmingly positive, as you would expect. The good news for us is our comparable margins have held steady as we've have had the sales lift, and we've had good, strong flow-through to offset this kind of discounting. And our brand metrics are obviously improving certainly on the value side. So as we go forward, when we look at the overall category, we think everyday value is a fact of life, and that we're going to have to work very hard to make sure that we make everyday value a staple of Pizza Hut. And we will have some premium-priced pizzas, primarily those pizzas that we provide category breakthrough innovation around. But we're really working hard at attacking our cost structure and working with our franchisees to make sure that we continue a very strong everyday value proposition as we go forward. So I think you will continue to see great value coming from Pizza Hut, which is a terrific opportunity for us. And one thing we've learned is being premium priced in this kind of environment that we're in right now is certainly not the strategy anyone can pursue. And we think that we understand what we have to do in the pizza category and Scott Bergren and the Pizza Hut team are working hand in hand with our franchisees to come up with an enduring way to provide value.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer [UBS].
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer [UBS].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yum! delivered, I think it was 20% profit growth for the first half of the year, and China had drove 70% of that growth. And meanwhile, the U.S. was flat. Thinking about the second half as we think about and try to model the second half, it does seem ridi
componenttext: Yum! delivered, I think it was 20% profit growth for the first half of the year, and China had drove 70% of that growth. And meanwhile, the U.S. was flat. Thinking about the second half as we think about and try to model the second half, it does seem ridiculous, I guess, to expect 20% profit growth all the time. However, your guidance implies something close to the 10% profit growth in the second half. Could you help us think about why the profit growth would slow so significantly or why it might slow significantly?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me explain some of the dynamics, David, in the second half of the year. First of all, as a follow-up to the question that Jeff raised, we've talked about forex. Forex in the first half of the year, we had about a $28 million upside, and we just
componenttext: Well, let me explain some of the dynamics, David, in the second half of the year. First of all, as a follow-up to the question that Jeff raised, we've talked about forex. Forex in the first half of the year, we had about a $28 million upside, and we just sort of said in the second half of the year, that will slow to about a $5 million net upside. The cost dynamics in China are interesting, when you look at it on a first half, second half of the year basis. And that's probably the biggest shift that we'll see, is in the first half of the year, we had about $30 million of commodity deflation. And in the second half, we expect about $15 million of inflation, most of that in the fourth quarter. The second turnaround is labor. We expected labor inflation coming into the year. However, the labor inflation, some of the rates that have occurred were higher than our initial expectations. And so in the first half of the year, we had about $12 million year-over-year increase in labor. In the back half, we expect that to be about $32 million. So that's an extra $20 million of labor in the second half versus the first half. So if you add that up, there's a $45 million swing on commodities, $20 million swing on labor. And so that's what's sort of driving less profit growth in China in the second half than the first half. The last thing, which is just a hard thing to know, and as I said in my speech, we're more relying on sales in the second half of the year. This is just obviously an environment where sales are still fairly hard to come by. So that's sort of our expectations when we look at the balance of the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the follow-up would be on the pricing power in China and how that would have a sort of lags and leads impact to your business. You mentioned food and labor inflation in China. But for instance, if labor costs go up 8%, you should be able to offset
componenttext: I guess the follow-up would be on the pricing power in China and how that would have a sort of lags and leads impact to your business. You mentioned food and labor inflation in China. But for instance, if labor costs go up 8%, you should be able to offset that with one point of price, given that labor is a relatively low percent of your sales. Meanwhile, that labor inflation theoretically is your consumers making more money. So you just had some pricing roll-off in the second quarter here in China. I'm thinking about your pricing, how that will come into play. Maybe you're thinking pricing might come back late in the year, not enough to help you but set you up well for calendar '11. How should we think about that?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: That's exactly the way we are thinking about it, David. Obviously we know that we need to cover these inflation increases at some point with pricing. We still expect this to back up. We expect for the full year to have very healthy margins in China, growt
componenttext: That's exactly the way we are thinking about it, David. Obviously we know that we need to cover these inflation increases at some point with pricing. We still expect this to back up. We expect for the full year to have very healthy margins in China, growth on last year, which were also very healthy margins. So overall, we like where we stand. Regarding the ebbs and flows, to your point, we had an unbelievable position in the second quarter, where we had sort of relatively low labor cost, negative commodities and obviously solid same-store sales growth. In the later part of this year, we are having the inflation we talked about. Clearly though, we believe we have the pricing ability in China. We have arguably the strongest consumer brand in China. We have to take in pricing before. And If everybody's got labor inflation, I expect there to be pricing throughout the market, right? So I think the timing of that, to your point, is likely to be sort of late this year. They won't benefit this year but should cover us in 2011.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of John Glass [Morgan Stanley].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of John Glass [Morgan Stanley].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about on sales trends during the quarter? I think coming out of the first quarter, there was an excitement about the 4% comp because it was against a relatively difficult comparison relative to the rest of this year. This quart
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about on sales trends during the quarter? I think coming out of the first quarter, there was an excitement about the 4% comp because it was against a relatively difficult comparison relative to the rest of this year. This quarter, if you just use that two-year math, it wasn't quite as robust. And maybe, two-year comparisons just don't work anymore. So how do you think about x pricing the back half of the year in same-store sales in China? Has there been any material acceleration, deceleration patterns? Or is the 4% just a good number to plug in as we think about the back half of the year? And if you want to talk about the last six weeks since the quarter ended in China, that would always be helpful as well.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't really have anything to say about trends within the quarter or since the quarter. Short answer to your question, 5%, 4% is good as anything out there, but that's your judgment to make. It's really hard. We've looked at this a bunch of different w
componenttext: We don't really have anything to say about trends within the quarter or since the quarter. Short answer to your question, 5%, 4% is good as anything out there, but that's your judgment to make. It's really hard. We've looked at this a bunch of different ways internally, John, in terms of last year, two years. In this case, you almost have to go back three years because if you remember, the earthquake hit in the middle of 2008. So you had very strong growth in the first half of that year. So what we said at the end of the first quarter was that, I actually feel better now than I did at the end of the first quarter. First quarter, we had the same number, 4% growth. At that point, we actually said that's probably as good a number to use as any in the second quarter. But the first quarter was really just based on two months because of the way our calendar is set up in China, and some of that was a holiday period. So it's hard to get a read on it. At this point, we have three more months of information. We have three more months where the consumer confidence in China is higher than a year ago. And it's not off the charts yet, but it's slowly coming back. So I think that the Chinese consumer is improving sort of slowly but steadily. It isn't all the way back yet, but it's better than last year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: So your profit forecast would assume a 4% comp in China in the back half of the year?
componenttext: So your profit forecast would assume a 4% comp in China in the back half of the year?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to be that precise, in that neighborhood.
componenttext: I'm not going to be that precise, in that neighborhood.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the U.S. margins, how much of the improvement at KFC, and maybe just overall the U.S. margins, was temporary or helped by something you did, cutting labor, reducing labor, whatever? And how much of this is sustainable? In other words, the prof
componenttext: And then on the U.S. margins, how much of the improvement at KFC, and maybe just overall the U.S. margins, was temporary or helped by something you did, cutting labor, reducing labor, whatever? And how much of this is sustainable? In other words, the profits improvement we're seeing at KFC, is that something we ought to read through to the back half of the year?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's obviously a lot of moving factors when you look at margins. There's sort of two pieces that I think are harder to duplicate. One we've talked about which were commodities. We've had modest commodity deflation in the first half of the year. It
componenttext: Yes, there's obviously a lot of moving factors when you look at margins. There's sort of two pieces that I think are harder to duplicate. One we've talked about which were commodities. We've had modest commodity deflation in the first half of the year. It was $5 million in the first quarter, a little less than that in the second quarter. And we also benefited in the second quarter by a small reduction in discounting when you add it all up across the businesses. That I don't know whether that will repeat as well. Then on the flip side, we have done, we've gone hard after cost improvements. And I think some of those will continue in the back half. When we put it all together, we're assuming slightly positive margin improvements for the full year in the U.S.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Joe Buckley [Bank of America].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Joe Buckley [Bank of America].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Couple more questions on China. Talking about wage inflation, not your specific wage inflation but wage inflation across the country, and does the China team expect that to lead to better sales?
componenttext: Couple more questions on China. Talking about wage inflation, not your specific wage inflation but wage inflation across the country, and does the China team expect that to lead to better sales?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, just to review for people, we did expect labor inflation in the back half. This always happens, sort of consistent labor inflation. The piece that we were surprised at the level of is last year, labor inflation was maybe a little less than typ
componenttext: Yes. Again, just to review for people, we did expect labor inflation in the back half. This always happens, sort of consistent labor inflation. The piece that we were surprised at the level of is last year, labor inflation was maybe a little less than typical. And we had thought this year would be back to normal. What really happened is that this year, sort of they made up for last year being a light year. So you had higher-than-normal labor inflation. You would think that that's going to help consumers. It's hard to tell the timing of that. So in the long run, obviously, if more people have money in their pockets, they're going to spend some of that, but it's really hard for us to quantify. But obviously, the growing middle class in China is a benefit to us from a sales perspective but also from a development perspective as more trade zones come in. So it's not necessarily a bad overall development. It just sort of impacts our profit from quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And are you positioning the brand in any way to take advantage of what presumably would be higher income levels for your consumers?
componenttext: And are you positioning the brand in any way to take advantage of what presumably would be higher income levels for your consumers?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll let David talk a little bit about that. But I think we're already well positioned to that. KFC has always had a very strong image in China. So I think we've always positioned ourselves, even though a quick-service restaurant is somewhat aspirat
componenttext: Well, I'll let David talk a little bit about that. But I think we're already well positioned to that. KFC has always had a very strong image in China. So I think we've always positioned ourselves, even though a quick-service restaurant is somewhat aspirational. Pizza Hut, even more so. So as the consumers have more money, I think we're actually positioned pretty well. I don't know if David wants to...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I think people are going to have more money to spend throughout the day. And I think what we're doing now is with breakfast, with 24-hour service, with home delivery, basically, we're positioning ourselves to make our brand, which is clearly one of the st
componenttext: I think people are going to have more money to spend throughout the day. And I think what we're doing now is with breakfast, with 24-hour service, with home delivery, basically, we're positioning ourselves to make our brand, which is clearly one of the strongest consumer brands, if not the strongest consumer brand, in China available to customers anytime they want. So I think the team is doing a great job of positioning ourselves to take advantage of what's going to inevitably be growing buying power. I know you followed us for a long time. The number of middle-class consumers, the estimates just keep going up by the millions every year, and we don't see that getting any smaller. And then the average per capita income's getting higher and higher of that group. So this is all good news for us. We're very well-positioned at KFC. Also, Pizza Hut Casual Dining, which, remember now, we have 464 casual dining units. We're doing the same thing there. We've made our products more affordable. We're leveraging asset with tea time. We actually, during the tea time period, have a higher market share of beverage consumption than Starbucks would have in China. So I think all of the things that we're doing, I mean, are positioning us to take advantage of the growing buying power in this country. And separately, one of the big markets, there's no question, there isn't anybody that doesn't think that Pizza Hut Home Delivery isn't going to be a viable brand or category in China, and we're there. We also see the Chinese fast food category emerging, and we continue to make progress for East Dawning. So our strategy is to have the leading brands in every significant category. What we're trying to do is build every one of our brands into power brands so we can compete effectively. And as the buying power of the consumer increases, which it will inevitably do, we will be able to take advantage of it. One thing that's kind of interesting, I think if you guys were all in the call in the fourth quarter of last year, even the second quarter call last year, there's been concern as to whether we'd ever be able to grow our same-store sales again. So we're pretty pleased with the fact that we've actually grown our same-store sales this year, 4%. We're feeling very good that we've had two straight quarters of 15% system sales growth. And all of that, Joe, has been transaction driven with no pricing. We obviously have, with our brand, pricing power. And as you know, our profit target for China is 15%. Our profits year-to-date are up 35%. So we're pretty happy that we're ahead of schedule. And we're really happy that each one of our brands are stronger today than they were yesterday from a consumer perspective. So I think when you step back and look at where we're at with China, it would be pretty difficult to imagine a better scenario. We couldn't be happier. And we just keep growing talent like you can't believe there, and that's one of those intangibles that you can't see. But our talent level's better. Our operations continue to be best in class. We're leveraging the asset throughout the day. We're not even -- we're in 1,000 stores in home delivery, 1,000 stores in 24-hour service. We're just getting started. We expect to have at least 14,000 KFCs some day. So it's just a matter of time. I would say we'll have ebbs and flows in China. We'll have ups and downs and all that kind of good stuff, but we're really glad we're there. We're really glad we're there with the team that we have. We're really glad that we have the brands that we have. And this is a long-term proposition. And it's really great to get the short-term growth along the way.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Can I ask just one more, just on YRI? The confidence at the second half would be better. Can you talk a little bit about the Pizza Hut versus KFC performance at YRI and why the confidence in the second half?
componenttext: Can I ask just one more, just on YRI? The confidence at the second half would be better. Can you talk a little bit about the Pizza Hut versus KFC performance at YRI and why the confidence in the second half?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we mentioned YRI has been a pretty steady performer over the year. We're going to continue to have the development growth that we always have. You saw this. The second quarter results were a little bit better than the first quarter. We start
componenttext: Well, again, we mentioned YRI has been a pretty steady performer over the year. We're going to continue to have the development growth that we always have. You saw this. The second quarter results were a little bit better than the first quarter. We start lapping easier numbers as we get into the back half of the year. So we're lapping negative same-store sales in the back half of 2009. So we feel good about our ability to do that. On your Pizza Hut question, Pizza Hut has been several points behind KFC on a year-to-date basis, which isn't surprising given the environment. It's more casual dining and therefore premium priced. So that difference is there. I'm not sure if that will change much in the balance of the year. We've also struggled with Pizza Hut results in the U.K. year-to-date. And that's been some of the reason for the margin decline that you saw in the second quarter. We're working to make that better. And hopefully, that will be better in the second half of the year. So we expect margins to get a little bit better in the second half as well.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Rachael Rothman [Susquehanna Financial Group].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Rachael Rothman [Susquehanna Financial Group].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we've made quite a bit of progress over the years on this. And I think we've refranchised about 1,300 restaurants since we put this in place. However, one of the things we did as we waited really until the first quarter of this year, the end
componenttext: Well, again, we've made quite a bit of progress over the years on this. And I think we've refranchised about 1,300 restaurants since we put this in place. However, one of the things we did as we waited really until the first quarter of this year, the end of the first quarter, before we really marketed all of the KFCs. So the good news at least from the refranchising team's perspective is pretty much everything that we planned to refranchised is now in the market. So as I sort of said in my speech, we're really actively pursuing that. So we've got a lot of discussions on various size transactions. So it's really hard to predict when it will fall. So it's really hard. Even an annual estimate on this is tough, which is why and as I said in both our release and the speech that we plan to finish sometime in 2011. But I do feel still confident in that target. And I can't really discuss specific areas, but I do expect that you'll see clearly more numbers in the second half of the year than in the first half.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, 500 was our estimate for 2010. We really didn't comment further on that target today. Because as I've said, before, it's really hard to predict the timing. I think it will be -- I doubt it will be exactly 500 because they are lumpy, some of these tr
componenttext: Well, 500 was our estimate for 2010. We really didn't comment further on that target today. Because as I've said, before, it's really hard to predict the timing. I think it will be -- I doubt it will be exactly 500 because they are lumpy, some of these transactions that we're working on. But what we said is that we originally wanted to finish at the end of 2010. What we said now is we'll finish sometime during 2011.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Just in the second quarter, we happen to have a few Taco Bells. Most of our refranchising is Pizza Hut and KFC, but we had somebody franchising of Taco Bells. This is sort of the typical level that we've been doing each year, but they fell in the second q
componenttext: Just in the second quarter, we happen to have a few Taco Bells. Most of our refranchising is Pizza Hut and KFC, but we had somebody franchising of Taco Bells. This is sort of the typical level that we've been doing each year, but they fell in the second quarter. And those command a higher price.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein [Barclays Capital].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein [Barclays Capital].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of question in the U.S. business. One, just in terms of -- you mentioned obviously greater focus on value continues. Just wondering whether you can give us an update both at Taco Bell and Pizza Hut in terms of, whether it be the $2 meal or the $10
componenttext: Couple of question in the U.S. business. One, just in terms of -- you mentioned obviously greater focus on value continues. Just wondering whether you can give us an update both at Taco Bell and Pizza Hut in terms of, whether it be the $2 meal or the $10 promotion, in terms of what type of mix you're getting off of that? I mean, is it more just advertising bringing people in but not necessarily as many orders as you would expect? I'm just wondering if you can size up the mix, perhaps the average check, the profit contribution, whatever metrics on each on those two promotions that seemed to be working for you.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, David really talked about the strategy on value. At Pizza Hut, most of our sales are on the $10 pizza. So it's a predominant part of our business. On the $2 menu, that's been about 5% of our mix so far. Obviously, one of the things we are keeping ou
componenttext: Well, David really talked about the strategy on value. At Pizza Hut, most of our sales are on the $10 pizza. So it's a predominant part of our business. On the $2 menu, that's been about 5% of our mix so far. Obviously, one of the things we are keeping our eye on, Jeffrey, is how that mix, where that mix comes from and whether that changes over time. So far, it's pretty similarly to the test. Some of it's coming from the Why Pay More Menu. A fair chunk of it has come from there. But we'll keep an eye on that as we go forward. And that's helped drive transactions up at Taco Bell.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of on the margin side from the U.S., it looks like you mentioned the kind of commodity changes in most of the year. But we did see some pretty large swings in both labor and occupancy in terms of driving what was pressure in the margin first half
componenttext: In terms of on the margin side from the U.S., it looks like you mentioned the kind of commodity changes in most of the year. But we did see some pretty large swings in both labor and occupancy in terms of driving what was pressure in the margin first half to a meaningful expansion of margin, actually first quarter versus the meaningful expansion in the second quarter. I was just wondering whether those types of swings in labor and occupancy are sustainable? It seemed like the comps are relatively similar first and second quarter, but there was pretty drastic swing on the margin side. So I'm just wondering about those labor and occupancy components.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've benefited from refranchising. As we've done refranchising, that has helped the margins. That should be sustainable. And then we probably got a little higher swing than normal in some of our insurance costs. It's sustainable, but the hit in the
componenttext: Yes, we've benefited from refranchising. As we've done refranchising, that has helped the margins. That should be sustainable. And then we probably got a little higher swing than normal in some of our insurance costs. It's sustainable, but the hit in the second quarter was higher than normal. The benefit in the second quarter was higher than normal.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, that benefits both labor and occupancy because you've got workers' comp, insurance and labor, and you've got casualty and all the other general insurance in the other occupancy line.
componenttext: Jeff, that benefits both labor and occupancy because you've got workers' comp, insurance and labor, and you've got casualty and all the other general insurance in the other occupancy line.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a way to size up of the 150 -- well, maybe it's even more than that in terms of the swing versus the first quarter. But just how much insurance relate to that?
componenttext: Is there a way to size up of the 150 -- well, maybe it's even more than that in terms of the swing versus the first quarter. But just how much insurance relate to that?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think basically, generally, on the comment in the release, we put it in order of magnitude. So that's generally our direction on that kind of thing.
componenttext: No, I think basically, generally, on the comment in the release, we put it in order of magnitude. So that's generally our direction on that kind of thing.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly in terms of the cash usage, it looks like obviously the shift to share repurchase was on  in the second quarter with $115 million and debt paydown remains fairly modest. I'm just wondering, any updated thoughts in terms of the balance of eithe
componenttext: Just lastly in terms of the cash usage, it looks like obviously the shift to share repurchase was on  in the second quarter with $115 million and debt paydown remains fairly modest. I'm just wondering, any updated thoughts in terms of the balance of either holding cash versus how you think about repurchase versus for the dividend boost or debt paydown, whether there's any kind of swing on that? Or we should assume continued share repurchase like we saw in this quarter?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that first of all, the cash went up a little bit really just because of the timing of repatriating some money and driven largely by China. You'll see swings from quarter-to-quarter on that piece of it. So don't read too much into that. The r
componenttext: Well, I think that first of all, the cash went up a little bit really just because of the timing of repatriating some money and driven largely by China. You'll see swings from quarter-to-quarter on that piece of it. So don't read too much into that. The repurchase side, we're probably no change versus what we've said previously. We're going to continue to repurchase stock. The debt piece of it, we have a large payout, but that's really in 2011. That's a $600 million payout. We don't believe we'll touch any of that or have the opportunity to profitably pay that off in 2010. So I don't expect anything significant on that front.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Komp [Robert W. Baird].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Komp [Robert W. Baird].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: It's Jonathan Komp calling in for David. Just a quick follow-up question on trends in YRI. Specifically, I'm wondering if you can give a little bit more color on why you didn't see an even bigger sequential improvement during the second quarter, given tha
componenttext: It's Jonathan Komp calling in for David. Just a quick follow-up question on trends in YRI. Specifically, I'm wondering if you can give a little bit more color on why you didn't see an even bigger sequential improvement during the second quarter, given that comparisons were much easier and you also did benefit from the Chinese New Year shift? And then secondly, a follow-up to that, if there's anything unique about the comparisons in YRI during the back half that really give you confidence that trends will improve.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: We've pretty much covered most of the point so far, but let me just sort of put them together. One as we sort of said before, we are lapping easier numbers in the second half of the year, so we did have some improvement. Even if you factor out the Chinese
componenttext: We've pretty much covered most of the point so far, but let me just sort of put them together. One as we sort of said before, we are lapping easier numbers in the second half of the year, so we did have some improvement. Even if you factor out the Chinese improvement, we had some improvement from the second quarter to the first quarter. It's been sticky though for us in some of our developed markets. So we've seen, if you look at our splits you see in the Franchise business is doing well. A lot of those are those emerging markets we talked about. We haven't performed as well in some of our developed countries. So we've been a little slow in Australia, which you saw in the release, as well as Pizza Hut U.K. I don't see necessarily those changing a lot, but it should get a little bit better, again, as we get into the easier comparisons.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Larry Miller [RBC Capital Markets].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Larry Miller [RBC Capital Markets].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I did want to follow up on that refranchising question. Have you guys talked about at what ownership level you'd be at, at the end in 2011 for the KFC and Pizza Hut business? And then I had one other question about returns in China.
componenttext: I did want to follow up on that refranchising question. Have you guys talked about at what ownership level you'd be at, at the end in 2011 for the KFC and Pizza Hut business? And then I had one other question about returns in China.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: What we've said is overall for the U.S. is about 10%, and that we'd approach close to 5% at KFC and Pizza Hut.
componenttext: What we've said is overall for the U.S. is about 10%, and that we'd approach close to 5% at KFC and Pizza Hut.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you just give us a sense -- because I think you re-accelerated growth in Pizza Hut in China, it's about a year ago. And now you've had a pretty good sense of gauging returns. You said, "Clearly, things are better." Can you give us a sense how
componenttext: And then can you just give us a sense -- because I think you re-accelerated growth in Pizza Hut in China, it's about a year ago. And now you've had a pretty good sense of gauging returns. You said, "Clearly, things are better." Can you give us a sense how these returns are stacking up, just in absolute terms and then relative to KFC? And a lot of mention [ph] East Dawning. I know it's something you've been working on for quite a long period of time. How far off are you, you think, from figuring out the unit economics at that division?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Just, Larry, to make sure I understand the question, you're talking about new unit returns for Pizza Hut?
componenttext: Just, Larry, to make sure I understand the question, you're talking about new unit returns for Pizza Hut?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Casual dining in China.
componenttext: Casual dining in China.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to back up what Larry's referring to for the rest of the folks is that we sort of said that last year's slowed down development of Pizza Hut. And what was driving that is we were saying two instances where we weren't getting the types of returns that
componenttext: Just to back up what Larry's referring to for the rest of the folks is that we sort of said that last year's slowed down development of Pizza Hut. And what was driving that is we were saying two instances where we weren't getting the types of returns that we looked to get. One was what we call in-fill returns in tier one cities. So not in new trade area, but sort of trying to put one closer to an existing unit. And then the second was in some tier three cities. The second units that we're putting in tier three cities weren't performing as well. The good news is that we're still being pretty cautious on some of the tier one cities. The tier three are actually -- the results we've had are looking better. So we feel more confident in going into more and more tier three cities. And we slowly started to ramp back up the development in tier one. The returns on Pizza Hut are not significantly different than the KFC-type of returns. So we're talking cash paybacks in less than three years.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And then East Dawning, where you guys stand in terms of the unit economics.
componenttext: And then East Dawning, where you guys stand in terms of the unit economics.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll talk about the bit about the economics and let David talk about the concept. We are very hopeful about East Dawning because it's a big idea. The consumer side keeps getting better each year. The cooking platform, we're getting more and more confidenc
componenttext: I'll talk about the bit about the economics and let David talk about the concept. We are very hopeful about East Dawning because it's a big idea. The consumer side keeps getting better each year. The cooking platform, we're getting more and more confidence. Having said that, we're a long way away from having unit economics that will allow us to expand rapidly. So don't expect large increases in the near future.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: At the same time, I think we feel good about the progress that we've made. We've gone to a central kitchen, which is helping our unit economics. We've improved our everyday value proposition. We've got a beverage platform that we feel really good about, t
componenttext: At the same time, I think we feel good about the progress that we've made. We've gone to a central kitchen, which is helping our unit economics. We've improved our everyday value proposition. We've got a beverage platform that we feel really good about, that will help us leverage the asset even more throughout the day. And we continue to be confident that we will have a concept. We don't want to get the cart ahead of the horse here, and we've got enough great things to really help very definitively when we talk about KFC and Pizza Hut.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of John Ivankoe [JPMorgan].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of John Ivankoe [JPMorgan].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: A question on KFC, and I'm just going to ask you to step back a little bit and talk about kind of the success of Grilled Chicken, now that it's been in the system for a little bit over a year and what you would have done differently for that product to mo
componenttext: A question on KFC, and I'm just going to ask you to step back a little bit and talk about kind of the success of Grilled Chicken, now that it's been in the system for a little bit over a year and what you would have done differently for that product to more sustained sales, and if there's any lessons that you've learned there across all of your U.S. brands. And I mean I ask that in the context of the financial health of your franchisees and their willingness to participate in other initiatives that may actually cost the money upfront, whether it be operational or other physical asset investments just to keep that brand healthy so it can participate on the upswing in the next cycle?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I think Kentucky Grilled Chicken, if you look at all the brand majors, has done nothing but improve our position in the marketplace. As I mentioned to you earlier, the American Customer Satisfaction Index, we had an eight-point swing, which is the highest
componenttext: I think Kentucky Grilled Chicken, if you look at all the brand majors, has done nothing but improve our position in the marketplace. As I mentioned to you earlier, the American Customer Satisfaction Index, we had an eight-point swing, which is the highest of any major brands. So clearly, the Kentucky Grilled Chicken has made KFC in the U.S. much more relevant than it would have otherwise been. I think as you look at the current performance, we have about 10% to 15% mix of Kentucky Grilled Chicken. I was just reading the AKFC Quarterly (sic) [AKFCF Quarterly], which is the franchise magazine that the franchisees publish, and they tell it as a success and feel good about it, and we've got a base that we can build from. So I think that we're very pleased that we launched it. I think some challenges that we have is we're working on better consistency just in key size. And we've got a project that help us work on that with our suppliers. I think that's one thing that we think will help us get even more sustainability over the long term, just from a product perspective. But this product, John, as you know and I'm sure you've read it has had rave reviews from food critics. I mean it's an outstanding product. I mean there's no question about it. It's five-star taste. And it's been named Product of the Year of people in the industry who develop -- people have recognized our people who developed the product. So I think it was a huge win. When I look at KFC's prospects here in the U.S., I think we're working on the things that will really matter: improving our chicken on the bone with better balance between the fried and the grilled; introducing portable products. We now have an outstanding filet, grilled fillet and fried fillet that's allowing us to do products like the Double Down and also move into the sandwich arena. So that's been a big move forward for the brand. One of our big challenges is that our pricing approach is casual dining pricing because we're a high-end business. And when you have pricing that gets into the casual dining arena or close to it, there aren't too many concepts that are growing robustly today. So our value proposition is a major challenge for us as we go forward. I think as it relates to investment, that's one of the challenges that I think we do have with the KFC system. It is a tough time right now. Future investments will -- we need to get the business healthier. But we have an operating platform and equipment package that gives us more variety than we've ever had from an opportunity, from an innovation perspective. If you recall, KFC in the U.S. is the only place in the, world where we've invested in back-of-the-house capability for the franchisees because we felt it was so important for us to get into grilled chicken. We helped fund and finance the ovens. I think this shows how committed we are to growing the business here in the U.S. because this is the origin of the brand. And so I think the team here we have is outstanding at working hard in a difficult situation. And we think we'll have steady, slow but steady progresses as we go forward. The great news is that KFC outside the United States is something for the U.S. franchise system to aspire towards being. And we've got a team here very dedicated to making that happen, and we're going to be relentless in terms of making that happen because we think we could be much more proud of the KFC brand here in the U.S. Even though we're very proud of it, very proud of the origin, we think we can be even better. And our job is to push the franchise system into doing the things that need to be done: Improving ops, improving assets, improving our value proposition.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I know there was a lot of concern and it showed up in your P&L in the fourth quarter of 2009 in franchise expense. But I mean do you think that the overall financial health of the KFC franchise system in the U.S. is stable? Or I mean, are you concer
componenttext: Well, I know there was a lot of concern and it showed up in your P&L in the fourth quarter of 2009 in franchise expense. But I mean do you think that the overall financial health of the KFC franchise system in the U.S. is stable? Or I mean, are you concerned that there might be significant store closures in the future if things don't improve from a comp perspective?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the franchise stability, obviously, we've gone through a couple of lean years on sales. And so we are always taking a closer look at that. Things have actually improved over the last few quarters, so we're in better shape from a franchise heal
componenttext: In terms of the franchise stability, obviously, we've gone through a couple of lean years on sales. And so we are always taking a closer look at that. Things have actually improved over the last few quarters, so we're in better shape from a franchise health perspective in terms of that piece of it. So I would say that we are stable. In terms of closures over time, to David's point, we are going to have to keep reinvesting in assets. To the extent that people are unable to do that, that could lead to closures at the time we're not as focused on the store count in the U.S. the way we are at international.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, We want to have a quality system. If we can have 4,500 fantastic, great-looking KFCs, I'd rather have 4,500 great-looking KFCs, than 5,000 with 500 looking at being drive-by assets. So we are totally prepared to do whatever it takes to get this syste
componenttext: Yes, We want to have a quality system. If we can have 4,500 fantastic, great-looking KFCs, I'd rather have 4,500 great-looking KFCs, than 5,000 with 500 looking at being drive-by assets. So we are totally prepared to do whatever it takes to get this system to look like a leader, be a leader and get where we need to go. And it will take time. But make no mistake about it, we are totally committed to doing that. [indiscernible]. It's literally, what, it's about 3% of our total profits. My God, this is upside for us. And that's what we are really going after, working with our good franchise partners to make that happen.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Tom Forte with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Tom Forte with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: So the first was on the Taco Bell tested breakfast. I want to know if you feel any differently, given that since you first launched the test, you've seen Subway come into the space with kind of a value message and the rollout of the Dollar Menu at McDonal
componenttext: So the first was on the Taco Bell tested breakfast. I want to know if you feel any differently, given that since you first launched the test, you've seen Subway come into the space with kind of a value message and the rollout of the Dollar Menu at McDonald's for breakfast. And then second, just for my own curiosity, any comment on for Kentucky Fried Chicken, either margin impact or the mix from the Double Down?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: The Taco Bell breakfast program, we're continuing to be optimistic. Tucson was our original test market. McDonald's threw everything in the kitchen sink at us in terms of price discounting, and we're already at breakeven in Tucson. We're also in three oth
componenttext: The Taco Bell breakfast program, we're continuing to be optimistic. Tucson was our original test market. McDonald's threw everything in the kitchen sink at us in terms of price discounting, and we're already at breakeven in Tucson. We're also in three other markets that we're working towards that same goal. I just met with the franchisees two weeks ago, meeting with Greg Creed. We all know that the single biggest thing we can do in Taco Bell is to develop another $100,000 to $300,000 sales layer, because we've got the best unit economics outside of McDonald's that I think, or in the industry, second most profitable brand. So in our mind, breakfast is not a question of whether, it's a question of when. And we feel like we're making more and more progress, and we know how we can get even better. The other thing that we're very excited about is we have a beverage platform at Taco Bell that will be going into a complete market in launching. And our objective, right now when you upgrade our assets with our new Bold assets, you get a 7% to 8% increase in sales. We're hoping that it will take it to 15% to 16% increase, which will help fund more reinvestment in the Taco Bell. So the breakfast and beverage platforms, we think, are really very positive developments for us. And the only thing I can say is we're further along now than we were when I talk to you about it last time. We continue to make progress. But we're committed to these sales layers because this is what's going to really invigorate the brand. We think we should have 8,000 Taco Bells in the U.S. I mean, why not? Burger King does. And you can't tell me that Burger King has a more charismatic brand, more loved brand than Taco Bell. Taco Bell is a brand that everybody talks about. So we've got a great franchise, but we need $100,000 to $300,000 more in sales. So these big platforms are what we're really committed to getting after. The other thing, even with our existing equipment, we can get into home meal replacement. So we're bundling up our home meal replacement ideas, taco meals, Tuesday tacos, things like that, that we're working on, that also give us a chance to get some maybe lower-hanging fruit, easier-to-do, significant sales growth as we go forward. So I'm very optimistic, I think you can tell, about the Taco Bell brand. Right now, we've got transaction growth, slightly positive sales. But when I think of the future, it's really bright.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And Tom, regarding your other question, the mix of Double Down is immaterial to our margins. KFC margins will be driven more like sales, commodities, and things we have already talked about.
componenttext: And Tom, regarding your other question, the mix of Double Down is immaterial to our margins. KFC margins will be driven more like sales, commodities, and things we have already talked about.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: It was a talked about product. There's no doubt about that. It is one big eat, so if you haven't had it, give it a try.
componenttext: It was a talked about product. There's no doubt about that. It is one big eat, so if you haven't had it, give it a try.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the margin trends in the U.S. by concept. And for example, like Pizza Hut with since the launch of $10 Any and some of those other things, are restaurant level margins, not op margins but restaurant level margins, are they up
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the margin trends in the U.S. by concept. And for example, like Pizza Hut with since the launch of $10 Any and some of those other things, are restaurant level margins, not op margins but restaurant level margins, are they up year-on-year? Taco Bell was in the mid-18s last year. How is it trending? Is it up year-on-year? I mean it has to be some portion of those two in order to get to the total. They can't just be KFCs. So if you could help me a little bit understand the margin trends at Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, that would be great.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: The Pizza Hut margins are down slightly. Overall, the business proposition works with the $10 pizza because it's grown transactions. We're working very hard to work on the cost side to make that sustainable and affordable on a long-term basis. Nothing rea
componenttext: The Pizza Hut margins are down slightly. Overall, the business proposition works with the $10 pizza because it's grown transactions. We're working very hard to work on the cost side to make that sustainable and affordable on a long-term basis. Nothing really major to report on the mix. There's something happening within the Taco Bell portfolio, so we're really going to keep an eye on the sales. Sales will probably be the biggest driver there. The only thing that's unusual, KFC has benefited a little bit more because this year, they've gotten a disproportionate amount of the commodity benefits so far, and we expect that probably to continue a little bit as well in the back half of the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Since all the books are out, basically, it sounds like for all the anticipated refranchising, while we may have some gains or losses on refranchising, is it safe to assume that the impairments that you take when you put the units for sale have all been ta
componenttext: Since all the books are out, basically, it sounds like for all the anticipated refranchising, while we may have some gains or losses on refranchising, is it safe to assume that the impairments that you take when you put the units for sale have all been taken?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, what happens is the way the accounting works is that you try to estimate what the selling price is, and if that requires a write-down, you'd take that when it's launched. There's a percentage of goodwill write-off that we also take, that we don't tak
componenttext: Yes, what happens is the way the accounting works is that you try to estimate what the selling price is, and if that requires a write-down, you'd take that when it's launched. There's a percentage of goodwill write-off that we also take, that we don't take until the unit's sold. So when some of these units sell, you'll see some goodwill piece and same with lease liability.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Linda Farquhar with Friess.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Linda Farquhar with Friess.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a little more detail on your new growth markets, if you could. On India, I'm wondering when you get a sufficient scale there such that you can launch on TV and how you see that market ramp? And then in France, can you talk about any impact from the l
componenttext: Just a little more detail on your new growth markets, if you could. On India, I'm wondering when you get a sufficient scale there such that you can launch on TV and how you see that market ramp? And then in France, can you talk about any impact from the launch on national TV?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think with India, we have 70 KFCs. We already did television in India, and we're just continuing to build the brand and expand. And we're making good progress at KFC. The consumer response has been great. With France, we now have 100 restaurants in
componenttext: Yes. I think with India, we have 70 KFCs. We already did television in India, and we're just continuing to build the brand and expand. And we're making good progress at KFC. The consumer response has been great. With France, we now have 100 restaurants in France, which has enabled television for the first time. We launched the TV, and I think our sales were up about 15%, which is what we would typically expect in a new market like that. Continental Europe is a significant opportunity for us, and we're really at the ground stage there. Our unit economics are getting better and better because we have high volumes. We're actually getting close now in Germany as well. So we're making good progress there, and that's another significant opportunity for us even though they're typically so-called more developed markets.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: So is France or Continental Europe a bigger near-term opportunity than India? Or how would you characterize those opportunities?
componenttext: So is France or Continental Europe a bigger near-term opportunity than India? Or how would you characterize those opportunities?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: We're full speed ahead on India. We think India is  going to be a tremendous opportunity for us. And if you ever get a chance to go down there and meet with our team there, just like China, we have 100% Indian team. We have tremendous operations. We've go
componenttext: We're full speed ahead on India. We think India is  going to be a tremendous opportunity for us. And if you ever get a chance to go down there and meet with our team there, just like China, we have 100% Indian team. We have tremendous operations. We've gone to school on the China model. We're executing the China model in India with a superior talent, superior talent. So we're very, very bullish on India.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Sara Senatore with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Sara Senatore with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a quick question on the U.S. business. SG&A, I think, it looks like you've got some leverage there. And I just want to understand -- I'm sorry, actually just the overall SG&A, which is just to say, can you help me understand like what, if there's s
componenttext: I have a quick question on the U.S. business. SG&A, I think, it looks like you've got some leverage there. And I just want to understand -- I'm sorry, actually just the overall SG&A, which is just to say, can you help me understand like what, if there's sort of a minimum amount of SG&A that you need no matter how franchised you are? I know you took out some costs initially in anticipation of being a more franchised model. But is there something that -- is there more you can take out as you go from like 90% to 95% franchise in some of the U.S. businesses, or as your YRI becomes a bigger piece of the business? Just trying to think about what kind of minimum overhead you need regardless of whether or not -- of what the franchise mix is. And then I had a follow-up on YRI. Just looking at disaggregating the markets. You said emerging markets were better. Is it fair if I look at the systemwide sales growth x FX is due to comp trends? Does the order of magnitude of comp trends match the order of magnitude of systemwide sales? Or is there faster unit growth in some of these markets that might explain some of that?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the last part, Sara. On the emerging markets, I think, what you're trying to get at, and we said 10% system sales growth for emerging markets and about flat for the developed. The unit growth on the developed side is roughly longer terms, abou
componenttext: I'll answer the last part, Sara. On the emerging markets, I think, what you're trying to get at, and we said 10% system sales growth for emerging markets and about flat for the developed. The unit growth on the developed side is roughly longer terms, about a plus one. And on the emerging markets, I believe its about seven. And hopefully, that gives you an idea. I think that's what you're looking for.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the G&A, again, when we started the program, we looked 1at the G&A that would be reduced. And we sort of said that it would be close to offsetting the loss we'd have in trading out from restaurant margin to royalties. We've now said we'll do at lea
componenttext: And on the G&A, again, when we started the program, we looked 1at the G&A that would be reduced. And we sort of said that it would be close to offsetting the loss we'd have in trading out from restaurant margin to royalties. We've now said we'll do at least that well, maybe even a little better. So we've got a head-start on that though. We decided at the beginning of 2009 really to take a fairly significant G&A reduction. So right now, what the reduction that occurs now is mostly, I'll call it, store-related type of G&A. So area coaches and those types of moves. But when you put it together, we're still confident that we could at least offset the amount of trade-down we get between restaurant margin and royalty. So that's why we have sort of said we can make at least as much money at KFC on a long-term basis because we're still confident that, that math will work for us, with the G&A reduction and the royalty will be at least the size of what we're making in restaurant margin today.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Mitch Speiser with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Mitch Speiser with Buckingham Research.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Just another question on YRI. You did talk about the developed markets at Pizza Hut U.K., in particular, that it was soft. Can you maybe go through maybe two or three other developed markets and just give us a sense of how the comps trends have been versu
componenttext: Just another question on YRI. You did talk about the developed markets at Pizza Hut U.K., in particular, that it was soft. Can you maybe go through maybe two or three other developed markets and just give us a sense of how the comps trends have been versus maybe the first quarter and fourth quarter? Have things gotten a little bit better or a little bit worse? And separately on YRI, can you give us your general food cost outlook? Should we see food cost upticking for the YRI division in the back half as well?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the second part first is we really don't expect anything material on the YRI side on commodities in the second half of the year. We haven't seen a lot in the first half, too. So we look at that as pretty level in the first half, pretty level i
componenttext: Let me take the second part first is we really don't expect anything material on the YRI side on commodities in the second half of the year. We haven't seen a lot in the first half, too. So we look at that as pretty level in the first half, pretty level in the second half. If you look at just the two biggest company-owned markets that are developed are Australia and the U.K. And they were one point better in the second quarter than the first quarter, so I wouldn't really call that a trend. So things are still a little soft there. I don't have anything to really forecast on those for the balance of the year. I just do want to say, because we talked that the Pizza Hut U.K. business have been soft, but the KFC U.K. businesses, especially over the last several years, has performed really well. And they are performing, I think, pretty well in this environment. So I think that team has done a heck of a job, not just this year but in previous years. If you look at the developing markets again, you see that the trends -- the thing that was sort of noteworthy to me there was the Middle East number, where the macros there have improved somewhat, but not really to the extent at which we grew there as well. So again, I just want to sort of give a shout-out to the team in the Middle East has also done a really good job in this environment.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And we have a follow-up question coming from the line of David Palmer with YBS (sic) [UBS].
componenttext: And we have a follow-up question coming from the line of David Palmer with YBS (sic) [UBS].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: You pretty much answered my question which was the fact that it looked like Asia and Latin America and Middle East improving recently, developed markets on maybe a shallow recovery from a sluggish start. Is that really how you would sum up the consumer an
componenttext: You pretty much answered my question which was the fact that it looked like Asia and Latin America and Middle East improving recently, developed markets on maybe a shallow recovery from a sluggish start. Is that really how you would sum up the consumer and sort of the invisible hand of the consumer as you look at your numbers?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a pretty good summary. I think that the consumer in developed markets is still uncertain, a little uneasy. And therefore, we're not expecting. We're not planning for a remarkable recovery of the consumer there. We're looking at that as
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a pretty good summary. I think that the consumer in developed markets is still uncertain, a little uneasy. And therefore, we're not expecting. We're not planning for a remarkable recovery of the consumer there. We're looking at that as hopefully a steady recovery off of what's still a low base. In the developing market, those seemed to have -- they always were pretty good and they are starting to take maybe a bit more life.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: And there are no further questions at this time.
componenttext: And there are no further questions at this time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-14-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, let me briefly wrap up our comments today by saying that as a result of our strong year-to-date profit performance, we are raising our full year EPS growth target to 12%, excluding special items. Remember, we're going to be relying on sustaine
componenttext: Okay. Well, let me briefly wrap up our comments today by saying that as a result of our strong year-to-date profit performance, we are raising our full year EPS growth target to 12%, excluding special items. Remember, we're going to be relying on sustained China sales performance and improved same-store sales growth at Taco Bell and YRI in the second half of the year to achieve our target. We are especially pleased with our leading position in China, where our strategy is to build the leading brands in every significant restaurant category. And I hope we've shed what's the proper light on that today. We continue to execute against our global growth opportunities, especially in the emerging markets. There is no doubt that we are well positioned in the fastest-growing economies of the world with rapidly expanding middle-class populations. We are making progress in our U.S. business, and we're confident in delivering 12% EPS growth this year, making 2010 our ninth consecutive year of delivering our annual target of at least 10%. Thank you very much for being on the call. I enjoyed taking your questions, and have a great week.
