headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on YRI. I was a little bit surprised and very pleased, actually, with the margins. And I was wondering if you could talk about how you achieved that leverage with a 1% 1-year and 2-year comp? Maybe some more details around this.  Was this
componenttext: Just a question on YRI. I was a little bit surprised and very pleased, actually, with the margins. And I was wondering if you could talk about how you achieved that leverage with a 1% 1-year and 2-year comp? Maybe some more details around this.  Was this refranchising? What else contributed to that, to the leverage on that margin with a 1% comp?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: The two biggest leverages this quarter, Keith, first, on the margins, you hit it right, it was refranchising. So that had a significant impact on the margins this quarter. In terms of the other P&L leverage we got, we did have G&A leverage. And this quart
componenttext: The two biggest leverages this quarter, Keith, first, on the margins, you hit it right, it was refranchising. So that had a significant impact on the margins this quarter. In terms of the other P&L leverage we got, we did have G&A leverage. And this quarter was a bit higher than most, because we were overlapping a convention we had in the third quarter last year. But generally, on an ongoing basis, we usually expect to see around 6% type of system sales growth and then modest leverage in the rest of the cost structure to get to our 10% target.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: With this Mexico refranchising, it's quite a few units. How do you anticipate this impacting, let's say, company restaurant margins for YRI going forward?
componenttext: With this Mexico refranchising, it's quite a few units. How do you anticipate this impacting, let's say, company restaurant margins for YRI going forward?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: It will improve the numbers. We'll give you more input on that in the December meeting, but we think it will improve the margins and, actually, slightly help our profitability in 2011.
componenttext: It will improve the numbers. We'll give you more input on that in the December meeting, but we think it will improve the margins and, actually, slightly help our profitability in 2011.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Buckley of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Buckley of Bank of America.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions on China as well. The labor costs were up, as you mentioned. Could you talk about the wage rate inflation you experienced through your system? And then could you talk about how sales fared in markets where wage rate inflation was highe
componenttext: Couple of questions on China as well. The labor costs were up, as you mentioned. Could you talk about the wage rate inflation you experienced through your system? And then could you talk about how sales fared in markets where wage rate inflation was higher rather than lower?  Did you in fact see that sales lift from wage levels going up overall throughout the country?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have not looked at the second part of your question, Joe, so I haven't looked at the parts and in between why rates are little higher in sales growth. Because, generally speaking, the percentage increases over time have been fairly similar, but it's som
componenttext: I have not looked at the second part of your question, Joe, so I haven't looked at the parts and in between why rates are little higher in sales growth. Because, generally speaking, the percentage increases over time have been fairly similar, but it's something we'll probably take a look at. Typically, we usually see about 8%- to 10%-type of labor inflation. So this quarter and next quarter was a bit higher than that. We'll probably see that again in the first half of next year.  As we said, it had the unusually high increase sort of at the midpoint this year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just one more, I think you mentioned $15 million in full year benefits from the World Expo. I guess there's another $5 million coming in the fourth quarter. And talk about how that comes in? Is there a revenue number associated with that $15 million o
componenttext: And just one more, I think you mentioned $15 million in full year benefits from the World Expo. I guess there's another $5 million coming in the fourth quarter. And talk about how that comes in? Is there a revenue number associated with that $15 million of operating profit? Just to help us understand the margins a little bit better.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, the benefit is basically just as if it's a company-owned store, and it actually is.  So you see it in company sales and in company restaurant operating costs. So it's a benefit to restaurant margin, benefit to profit. It's excluded from the 14 restau
componenttext: Joe, the benefit is basically just as if it's a company-owned store, and it actually is.  So you see it in company sales and in company restaurant operating costs. So it's a benefit to restaurant margin, benefit to profit. It's excluded from the 14 restaurants in the Expo or were excluded from the unit count, because they're only temporary. And the same-store sales number that we gave excludes the sales benefit.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the operating profit margin on those 14 restaurants, would it be comparable to what you reported?
componenttext: And the operating profit margin on those 14 restaurants, would it be comparable to what you reported?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably higher.
componenttext: Probably higher.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays Capital.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, just first, a follow-up on China. I think you mentioned for the fourth quarter, you'd expect comps to kind of run similar to what you were running year-to-date, which, I think, was 5%. I know the compares ease a few hundred basis points, an
componenttext: Two questions, just first, a follow-up on China. I think you mentioned for the fourth quarter, you'd expect comps to kind of run similar to what you were running year-to-date, which, I think, was 5%. I know the compares ease a few hundred basis points, and I don't know if there were any unusuals. Because I know it seems like consumer confidence continues to improve, I would think you'd expect that comp trend to continue to improve from the 6% we saw here. And then, when you look out to 2011, is it reasonable to assume a further comp recovery, or do you think the recovery state is over, and now, perhaps, it's more appropriate to assume more of a low single-digit comps as your penetration grows and you push more in the direction of maturity? And then I have a follow-up question on cash.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, regarding long-term comps is that we haven't looked into 2011 a lot of detail yet. But typically speaking, our model looks in the 3% to 5% range of same-store sales to make our model work. So that's sort of a typical type of number and obvio
componenttext: First of all, regarding long-term comps is that we haven't looked into 2011 a lot of detail yet. But typically speaking, our model looks in the 3% to 5% range of same-store sales to make our model work. So that's sort of a typical type of number and obviously, depending on the cost structure and the inflation environment. In terms of -- we sort of covered this on some of the previous calls, looking in two-year, three-year, one-year comps and looking at when the inflection points were with the earthquake and the softening of the economy at the end of 2009, we think the year-to-date number's as good a number as anything for the fourth quarter. One of the challenges on the consumer confidence side is, even though it's better than year-ago, it sort of flattened out in terms of the improvement rates. We're seeing year-over-year improvement, but we're not seeing accelerated improvement in consumer confidence. So we're with you trying to read the tea leaves, so we see a -- it's a better economy not yet booming.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just separately, Rick, on the cash usage side. I know the cash position continues to increase pretty meaningfully.  It more than doubled relative to last quarter. Back then, a part of it was just due to repatriation timing, but it doesn't seem li
componenttext: And then just separately, Rick, on the cash usage side. I know the cash position continues to increase pretty meaningfully.  It more than doubled relative to last quarter. Back then, a part of it was just due to repatriation timing, but it doesn't seem like the major debt due -- I mean this kind of million in debt due in '11 for which you did this debt offering.  But should we expect share buyback to increase meaningfully for the rest of this year and into '11? I'm just wondering how you determine the timing and, perhaps, the open amount of repurchase with only, it looks like, $30 million in the third quarter, less than $300 million year-to-date. Just trying to size it up, kind of the timing and how you determine the amount to repurchase.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: We expect that we'll probably have more share repurchases in the fourth quarter than in the third quarter, and then we expect more share repurchases right now in 2011 and 2010. But we don't have real specific numbers. Again, we'll try to share some of tha
componenttext: We expect that we'll probably have more share repurchases in the fourth quarter than in the third quarter, and then we expect more share repurchases right now in 2011 and 2010. But we don't have real specific numbers. Again, we'll try to share some of that with you in December.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Back to China comps for a moment.  Do you have any better clarity or visibility on what you think the benefits of the 24 hours and the breakfast had on comps this quarter? And what are the updated thoughts on pricing strategy? Are you going to take pricin
componenttext: Back to China comps for a moment.  Do you have any better clarity or visibility on what you think the benefits of the 24 hours and the breakfast had on comps this quarter? And what are the updated thoughts on pricing strategy? Are you going to take pricing late this year and it's going to impact next year?  Or are you going to wait until next year to talk about pricing or do pricing in China?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think the benefits that some of the ops initiatives that we talked about, 24 hour delivery, et cetera, is probably in the 1% to 2% range. I probably expect a similar kind of number next year, a little early to tell. Regarding pricing, don't expect much
componenttext: We think the benefits that some of the ops initiatives that we talked about, 24 hour delivery, et cetera, is probably in the 1% to 2% range. I probably expect a similar kind of number next year, a little early to tell. Regarding pricing, don't expect much impact at all. As I said in my remarks in the fourth quarter, we'll probably have some modest pricing increase either late this year or early next year. Beyond that, we'll have to wait and see what our inflation expectations are.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, as it relates to the refranchising strategy at YRI, what is it? At this point, I think this transaction is roughly 20% of your company units, which is material. Do you expect that there'll be other large transactions like this in the next 18 to
componenttext: And then, as it relates to the refranchising strategy at YRI, what is it? At this point, I think this transaction is roughly 20% of your company units, which is material. Do you expect that there'll be other large transactions like this in the next 18 to 24 months in other, more mature YRI markets? Or was this really just a one-off, and we shouldn't expect to see a real change in the percentage ownership in YRI going forward?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what happens at YRI, as you know, John, we are at the same time building units in the developing markets at places like India, and also for us underdeveloped markets like France are also companies. So we'll be adding on that side. At the same time,
componenttext: Well, what happens at YRI, as you know, John, we are at the same time building units in the developing markets at places like India, and also for us underdeveloped markets like France are also companies. So we'll be adding on that side. At the same time, we'll do selective refranchising. We'll do some more selective refranchising, probably not the size. You shouldn't expect, next year, to see something of the size of Mexico, though.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rachael Rothman of Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rachael Rothman of Susquehanna.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I missed this, but can you talk about, maybe, traffic trends in each of your three key regions? I think somebody asked about pricing power. But just backward-looking, how has traffic been diverging or following along with same-store sales?
componenttext: I don't know if I missed this, but can you talk about, maybe, traffic trends in each of your three key regions? I think somebody asked about pricing power. But just backward-looking, how has traffic been diverging or following along with same-store sales? That would be great.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: In China, most of the increase has been transactions. So almost all of it. We have had that very small levels of pricing this year. So it's pretty much all transaction-driven. Generally speaking, if you look at the U.S., you'll probably get a couple of po
componenttext: In China, most of the increase has been transactions. So almost all of it. We have had that very small levels of pricing this year. So it's pretty much all transaction-driven. Generally speaking, if you look at the U.S., you'll probably get a couple of points of pricing. So if you look at our same-store sales numbers and took off a couple of points for Taco Bell and KFC, you'd probably get close. Pizza Hut is a different story, because there, we've actually had a net pricing decline.  Our transactions are significantly above our growth rate.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then YRI, has it been price or traffic?
componenttext: And then YRI, has it been price or traffic?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: YRI has mostly been traffic.
componenttext: YRI has mostly been traffic.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I could just follow-up on China, can you talk about, maybe, same-store sales growth trends in the newer markets versus the developed markets?
componenttext: And then if I could just follow-up on China, can you talk about, maybe, same-store sales growth trends in the newer markets versus the developed markets?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, the same-store sales growth this year has been very balanced across all the tiers and all the geographies.
componenttext: Actually, the same-store sales growth this year has been very balanced across all the tiers and all the geographies.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Senatore of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Senatore of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not surprisingly, another question on China and then a separate one, actually, that's a little bigger picture. So on China, you said you've taken very little price, but it was noticed that the inflation data out of China are positive and have gotten a lit
componenttext: Not surprisingly, another question on China and then a separate one, actually, that's a little bigger picture. So on China, you said you've taken very little price, but it was noticed that the inflation data out of China are positive and have gotten a little bit more positive. So I guess I'm trying to think about, let's call it cross price elasticity. So what some of your competitors might be doing or what food at home might be doing, and does that give you a little bit more leeway in terms of if you don't take price, you've gained some of the traffic. Just trying to think about how your pricing compares in China to substitutes, like either away from home or at home? That's the first question.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had some, I'd say, unusual commodities in China over the last few years. I'm not sure if we would have mirrored the at-home market. Chicken, obviously, did go up a lot at one point late '08. So other commodities have grown at different rates. We don't
componenttext: We had some, I'd say, unusual commodities in China over the last few years. I'm not sure if we would have mirrored the at-home market. Chicken, obviously, did go up a lot at one point late '08. So other commodities have grown at different rates. We don't have a lot of great information, at least I haven't seen, on cross-elasticity between the take-homes and take-away markets in China. Clearly, it is going to be more sensitive on the economy, as people there generally have lower incomes. So usually, with something as a higher percentage of your ticket there, you're going to have more impact in the restaurant business when the economy is weaker than you probably would in the grocery side. That would be my guess, but I don't have data that would back that up.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the broader-picture question, you talked a lot about emerging markets and how you're the fastest grower there or the biggest presence. Can you just talk broadly about why that is? And so far,  you're certainly bigger than a lot of restaurant comp
componenttext: And then the broader-picture question, you talked a lot about emerging markets and how you're the fastest grower there or the biggest presence. Can you just talk broadly about why that is? And so far,  you're certainly bigger than a lot of restaurant companies with whom you might have compete, but there are other scaled restaurant companies. So is something about your supply chain? Do you own more of your supply chain? Is it something about how you run your businesses? If could you just maybe talk about some of the advantages that sustain that faster pace?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think KFC is our biggest brand outside of the U.S. today. KFC has a big advantage of being very popular protein where we brought a tremendous image, a unique image, to a known quantity, and we've been able to grow. We were blessed to have a number of ve
componenttext: I think KFC is our biggest brand outside of the U.S. today. KFC has a big advantage of being very popular protein where we brought a tremendous image, a unique image, to a known quantity, and we've been able to grow. We were blessed to have a number of very aggressive and top-flight franchisees who've invested in the markets for years before other competition ever even entered and still has yet to enter. For example, in Vietnam, McDonald's isn't even in Vietnam. So I think it's the protein of choice with the unique brand combined with tremendous franchisees who have invested in the supply chain.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mitch Speiser of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mitch Speiser of Buckingham Research.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on food cost and, of course, we all know that you're very much a franchise organization. But still the store-level margins do have an impact on earnings per share. Just to try to get a sense, with corn up now about 40% year-over-year and ma
componenttext: My question is on food cost and, of course, we all know that you're very much a franchise organization. But still the store-level margins do have an impact on earnings per share. Just to try to get a sense, with corn up now about 40% year-over-year and maybe just looking at the U.S. business in particular, how does that flow through to your P&L if costs are at this rate today? Does it take three or six months for that to be felt through the P&L? Just trying to get a sense of the sensitivity to that and the timing as well.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll answer that in two pieces. There are some things that you know will go up a bit. So we will be signing some contracts on certain items soon for 2011. But part of the impact this year, Mitch, is that you're probably going to be less further out
componenttext: Well, we'll answer that in two pieces. There are some things that you know will go up a bit. So we will be signing some contracts on certain items soon for 2011. But part of the impact this year, Mitch, is that you're probably going to be less further out in hedging given the volatility, because it gets more expensive to hedge in that kind of situation. Plus with speculators in, a lot of people don't want to hedge when speculators are in, because the feeling is when they go out, the prices will go back down. So probably just the reality is we probably have a little bit more uncertainty than usual. And right now, if you looked at the numbers, we'd probably expect in an area of about a 3% increase in the U.S.  But a lot could happen between now and the start of the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney of Hedgeye Risk Management.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney of Hedgeye Risk Management.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it's not unprecedented for dominant brands to lower prices to drive traffic, and I think you've obviously done it, and different consumer categories have done it. You've struggled with KFC for a number of years, tried a number of different new pro
componenttext: I guess it's not unprecedented for dominant brands to lower prices to drive traffic, and I think you've obviously done it, and different consumer categories have done it. You've struggled with KFC for a number of years, tried a number of different new products. Is lowering prices not the right strategy? I mean, it's been successful for Pizza Hut here recently. Why isn't just bringing the price points down for KFC the right strategy to get people back in the door?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Howard, I actually think you have a pretty good comment there, that I think the brand is very well aware of our value ratings are not as high as they should be in the category, KFC, because it's primarily chicken-on-the-bone dinner business. It has pricin
componenttext: Howard, I actually think you have a pretty good comment there, that I think the brand is very well aware of our value ratings are not as high as they should be in the category, KFC, because it's primarily chicken-on-the-bone dinner business. It has pricing that's closer to casual dining than it does typical fast food. We have a number of things in test right now to enhance and improve our value. And the test market results where we've gone aggressive enough are definitely moving in the right direction. So we don't have anything to really announce on that. But that's clearly an area of opportunity for us that you've identified, we've identified, the consumer has told us it's an opportunity, and we're working hard on it.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are no further questions at this time.
componenttext: There are no further questions at this time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just wrap things up. We had a solid quarter and have had a great year so far. We're pleased with the performance of our business units, specifically our strong performance in China. We are confident in delivering our raised target of 14% EPS
componenttext:
Well, let me just wrap things up. We had a solid quarter and have had a great year so far. We're pleased with the performance of our business units, specifically our strong performance in China. We are confident in delivering our raised target of 14% EPS growth. We continue to execute against our global growth opportunities, especially in emerging markets. There is no doubt we are well positioned in the fastest-growing economies of the world with rapidly expanding middle-class populations. We're making progress in our U.S. business. We're confident in delivering 14% EPS growth, making 2010 our ninth consecutive year we meet or exceed our target of at least 10%. And we're very confident about our continuing track record for 2011. 
Our significant and growing exposure to the explosive growth in China, the rest of Asia and emerging markets gives us an unprecedented short- and long-term opportunity. We look forward to sharing more on this in December and seeing you at our Annual Investor Conference. Thank you very much.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2010
